title: A True Classic in the YA Genre
text:
There aren't many people out there who haven't read Lois Lowry's classic, The Giver, but I happened to be one of them. Then I talked to my longtime friend (since 2nd grade!) who I often share great YA titles with (and a love for cheesy RomComs) and she told me The Giver was a book that she read in middle school that stayed with her. She still thought about the book 20 years later (god we are getting old). So, I decided I had to quit being a turd and do my YA collection justice with this 1994 Newberry winner. After finishing it in one voracious sitting, I had to ask myself if I would ever learn. I avoided Percy Jackson for years- did I learn? I refused to read Harry Potter, Twilight, and so many more for no other reason than they were popular. Now The Giver. Will I ever learn?! Why do I deprive myself of great stories?

The story begins in a utopia. No one feels pain, no one is unhappy. Any feelings of anger, jealousy or concern are to be voiced in family units every morning in order to address and release them. Children are not born and raised with their parents. Instead, a sensible couple the community puts together is allowed to ask for children and they can receive up to one boy and one girl. Only Birth Mothers are allowed to have children, but since all the community members take drugs to inhibit sexual impulses from the time they reach puberty, no one seems to object. When people get too old, they are "Released" into a better state. If twins are born, the smaller of the two will be released. Even careers are not chosen, but rather given to the people of the community by the Elders after careful consideration. When children reach their twelfth year, they are assigned a career to focus on. Although they can request a career change, it doesn't happen. Instead, people are content in the community. They contribute, they live, and they are content. Nothing more. Nothing less.

When Jonas reaches his twelfth year and is assigned, however, it changes everything. Jonas is assigned as the new Receiver of Memory. He is to report to the Giver of Memory, an old man who was chosen as Jonas was chosen, to be given the memories of times forgotten. This includes happy memories, like snow, sledding, warm sun, and fun. It also includes bad memories like pain, breaking an arm, war, and anger. These memories begin to change Jonas, but he is forbidden to share them with others. All he wants to do is show his sister and his friends the colors of the world, the sunshine.

When his father, a Nurturer in the nursery, brings home a baby who isn't sleeping well, Jonas takes him into his bedroom at night and shares the happy memories with him. This soothes the baby, but is strictly forbidden, of course. Jonas and the Giver begin talking about leaving the community in order to give the people back the memories of past times, good and bad. It will be traumatic for them, but The Giver will be there to guide them. When Jonas's father announces the baby is going to be "released", Jonas, who has seen what "releasing" really is, refuses to leave the baby to that fate.

This story is one that will truly rock your world. With so many dystopias swirling around out there, it is hard to imagine one that could sweep you off your feet as easily as this one. Nevertheless, this classic bested me. It makes the reader question their wants, their desires, their hopes. It keeps the reader on their toes and examines what is really important in life. Do we need a life free of pain and suffering? Or will that lead to the loss of all this beautiful, wonderful, and sublime as well. Do we need to experience pain in order to truly know love and happiness when we have it?

This book is a must read for anyone who hasn't read it already. Recently a coworker said she was using it in her middle school Lit class, and I was thrilled! (eerily she told me about using it in her classroom the very same day I finished reading it!) To hand this story over to students, especially in a student-driven setting, means opening the door to struggling readers who can't get enough of a story. This will be that story- it will have them questioning everything they have ever known, and then some. And isn't that why we read anyway? To question ourselves, our worlds, what we know, what we think we want to know, and so much more? Don't be afraid to give this story to your children or students- like my grade school friend, they will never forget it!

text: A typical example of a Spenser book. Something fishy is going on in Blackburn. Kids are being sent to a " juvenile center", played on an island in Boston bay, some for actions that are not a crime. A mom hires Spenser to help get her son off the island.  Spenser discovers mob connections and crooked judges.  The gang is back including Susan and Hawk.

title: Amazing true story
text: I enjoyed this sequel to Caroline Jessop's autobiography , Escape. This book tells of her difficult life after leaving the FLDS and her abusive husband Merril Jessop. Caroline worked very hard to provide for her eight children, and acclimatize them to normal life outside The Church. Her eldest daughter Betty wanted to return to her father and eventually did so and refuted Caroline's statements. Caroline became a political consultant on this sect, especially  during the raid of the YFZ ranch in Texas where the group had built a new temple. She also spoke out against Warren Jeffs who had taken over as the living Prophet of the sect. Her ex-husband Merril sued for custody which he lost and also owed thousands in child support which he did not pay. He was  imprisoned with Jeffs for his crimes. Caroline is an amazingly strong selfless woman who sought a better life for her own children and all the victims of the sect. She eventually found a true romance and a man who could properly love her children. She richly deserves a happy life.This is an excellent book both on a personal level but about the FLDS as well.

title: Great Contributions to Columbia SC Social Life
text: Beautiful recounting of Isabel Whaley Sloan’s contribution to the young social life of Columbia, SC, through dance instruction, etiquette, and arranging of USO dances at Ft Jackson.  Always conscious of appearances and social reputations, Isabel gave grace and guidance to many young women and men.  The book gives a little known look into the life and contributions by the daughter of noted Reconstruction Industrial Engineer William Burroughs Smith Whaley.

title: Outstanding police procedural...
text:
NO SPOILERS HERE. This first-in-series book kicks off with some interesting and multi-dimensional characters, Detective Inspector Moses Glynn and Detective Constable Juliette Rock, getting their inaugural case assignment with Division 43, a little known but well-equipped and high-powered intelligence branch of the police charged with investigating and squelching corruption at whatever level it is found. As would be expected when two people of dissimilar backgrounds and experiences are thrown together and tasked with achieving a specific goal, differences of opinion are inevitable and frequent. Against this backdrop of a new and unfamiliar work environment, a burgeoning new partnership, and each detective’s personal life issues, a complex case unfolds involving murder and police corruption on a mind-blowing scale. This story offers some amazing action, an original and meticulously cultivated plot, captivating twists and turns, and uncommonly vivid character development all while delivering a gritty and provocative police procedural which kept me turning pages late into the night. I loved that the author was able to convey a rather convoluted plot in such a way that it flowed smoothly and was easy to follow despite its complexity. I think the story and writing style will appeal to fans of Michael Connelly and James Patterson and I know I will certainly be eagerly anticipating more adventures with these remarkable and memorable characters.

I was provided with an advance copy of this book and I am voluntarily offering my honest and unbiased review.

title: My 2 & 5-Year-Old Love It in Different Ways!
text:
This book has become a favorite of my daughter's at bedtime (she's 2) over the last week or so. I tried reading it in its entirety to her, but her attention span is not quite there yet, so we just do "A is for Anteater" and so on. She started out just repeating the animal names, but now has started adding the letters before them. She will get the book on her own, and "read" it as she turns the pages. After some practice, she can even say the more difficult animal names like orangutan and kinkajou. She also LOVES the baby animals, and when we read it together she likes to point out which ones are the babies and which ones are the mommies. The illustrations are really lovely! Her only complaint is that P is for polar bear and not penguin, because penguins are her favorite, but we can't fault the book for that!

My son, who is 5, is really into learning facts (think NatGeo's "My First Big Book of..." series) and he really likes the animal facts that accompany each animal, especially the lesser-known animals. I think this is a great book for a varied age range, and am sure that as my daughter grows, she will begin to enjoy and benefit from the animal facts as well.

title: Making a Film or Video? Make It "Sticky" with "Lean Forward Moments"
text:
Humans love stories. We'll stop what we're doing to be an audience for a good story. But what makes a story good? Norman Hollyn offers some important clues for making a story come alive on the screen - whether it's a theater screen or a small netbook screen.

Hollyn teaches his readers to focus on details, the details that make the difference between a good story and a big yawn. How can a film show character, conflict, emotion, with more than just words? Hollyn shows how he does it, how the great directors have done it. He illustrates how the smallest detail can reinforce or destroy the mood of the story the videographer is attempting to create.

Where are these details? They appear throughout the entire process,

in the logline,
the writing,
the background and other production elements,
the directing and cinematography, and
the editing.

Maybe, although you've seen great films all your life, you've not been aware of the tiny (and not so tiny) details that lead you to a specific emotional state. Hollyn brings these details into your awareness and shows you how they work together to create a great story.

So how do his lessons apply in the chaotic world of video where creation and uploading can happen with hours, even minutes? Making videos people want to watch, want to learn from is a matter of careful planning and attention to detail of storyline, theme. and mood. Most of the videos that languish unappreciated lack his focus and attention, lack a clear direction with cinematic elements that support rather than distract from the message.

After reading this book, slowly savoring it, I will never again watch a film without at least minimal awareness of the cinematic elements used to create and reinforce a mood, and to draw me to the edge of my seat with a "lean forward moment." And, after reading it, I've got a much better idea of how to create videos with "lean forward moments."

Highly recommended - this book has a permanent spot in my library

title: Beautifully written, Engaging story
text:
Beach House Summer is a beautifully written, engaging story. This is a fun beach read of three women connected by past actions and learning the true meaning of family and friendships.

Joanna grew up in Silver Point, a small seaside community. She had a loving father who died when she was young, leaving her to a mean step-mother that didn't want her. She fell in love with her bestfriend's brother, Nate and thought she would finally have her happy family but when he broke up with her she ran away with Cliff, a famous chef. They married but life was anything but easy as Cliff was a serial cheater and lived for the limelight which she hated. A year after divorcing Cliff, she watches the devastating news that he was killed in a car accident and that a pregnant young woman was with him.

Ashley grew up with a "dad" she adored who passed away. She and her mom work hard to make ends meet but when her mom gets deathly ill, she reveals who Ashley's real dad is. Ashley is stunned and after her mother's passing does everything she can to meet her father including climbing in a car to have a conversation with him. She wakes up in a hospital and Cliff's ex-wife is there to whisk her away from the cameras and media. She is stunned by the generosity.

Mel is hurt and angry when her bestfriend breaks her twin brother's heart and leaves town. Now two decades later she learns that Joanna is back and living in her new old home. She confronts Joanna about the way she left and is confounded by Joanna's reaction. Later learning the true reason Joanna left has her re-examining all she thought was true. Now she tries to rebuild the close friendship but Joanna is still leery.

As Joanna and Ashley work to avoid the paparazzi and build a new life, they learn that small town communities protect their own and family is not always by blood. Joanna is tired of hiding and is learning to face life head on, the past is the past but some things are meant to last. Her friendship with Mel is one of them and she has also reconnected with Nate, her first love. This is a great story of rediscovery, recovery, growth and love.

I received an advanced readers copy from the publisher but all thoughts and feelings are my own.

title: Full of tasty oatmeal recipes!
text:
I first heard about Jenny Grothe in a recent issue of _Muscle and Fitness Hers_ magazine, where she had written an article with several really good recipes in it. The byline mentioned her book, but when I came here to Amazon to order it, I was a bit reluctant to do so at first since many of the reviewers only have one review -- which always makes me a bit nervous since when I notice this, I worry that the reviewers are friends of the author. I decided to take the plunge anyways, and am glad I did. This book has over 75 recipes for oatmeal in it, and all are delicious.

I love oatmeal so this book was right up my alley, but it has such tasty recipes in it that I can see non-oatmeal-lovers enjoying it, too. Most of the recipes focus on baked oatmeals, but there are also a few recipes for pancakes and bars thrown in, as well as recipes that call for other grains such as quinoa and muesli.

To give you an idea of what the recipes involve, they include ones like Black Forest Backed Oatmeal, Cinnamon Chocolate Chip Baked Oatmeal, and Key Lime Baked Oatmeal. The variety of recipes really does cover every palette, and they mostly call for simple ingredients that one might already have on hand or that are easy to find.

The prep time for each baked oatmeal recipe is minimal (less than five minutes), and each requires about 30 minutes of baking time.

I like, too, how this book starts with Jenny's own story of weight loss; it's very inspirational and motivating, and Jenny seems very sweet.

Also, although this book is small, almost every recipe has a full-color photograph, which I enjoy seeing in cookbooks. (The book might even be self-published and could have benefited from an editor to help catch typos, but those don't bother me since the recipes themselves are so good.) Overall, this is a great book to add to one's clean-eating collection! I hope she writes another cookbook soon!

UPDATE ON 7/30/11: I ordered this larger-sized ramekin [[ASIN:B00080QKKQ CorningWare French White 24-Ounce Round Dish]] and it works perfectly for all these recipes. The plastic lid also makes storing leftover baked oatmeals a breeze.

Although Amazon does carry a sampler pack of some sugar-free Torani syrups, they weren't the flavors that were most called for by this book. I ended up picking up a few at my local World Market, but then ordered more on the Torani website since they have so many flavors on their website that are hard to find in stores.

Every recipe I've made from this book has turned out to be incredibly delicious -- so much so that I was joking to my husband that I might start eating baked oatmeal as my three main meals each day!

title: Excellent introduction, but incomplete.
text: This is a first-rate introduction to CVS.  In fact, it may be that everything you ever need to know about CVS is in this book.  This book covers version control basics, paradigm differences, branches, merging, and all of the 'basic' version control tools.  It then provides 'recipes' (boiler plate) for common operations to simplify things.  This book has perhaps two shortcomings: first, it doesn't cover all of the features of CVS.  The authors can be forgiven for stating their prejudices, particularly since they coincide with mine, but I think completeness is worth something so ignoring the features that are deemed of less worth is probably not the best. Second, this book doesn't cover the GUI interfaces.  The GUI's should be easy to figure out, and the command line is certainly where it's at for scripting, but I think there are a lot of folks who would like at least a WinCVS appendix.  Overall, very recommended, but it won't make you a *complete* CVS guru.

title: One of the Best Nancys
text:
I've read all of the original Nancy Drew Mysteries from the '30s though the '50s, and this is one is at the top of my list. The Password to Larkspur Lane takes us back in time to an era when carrier pigeons and telegraphs still existed for communication, touring cars and roadsters could be seen on country lanes, doctors prescribed linament, women wore frocks and silk stockings, and men wore spats.

I love the way the story unfolds visually, almost like watching a movie. In the beginning we see Nancy in the garden picking larkspurs for a flower show. Later we picture her in her maroon roadster with the family's temporary maid, Effie, trying to follow the flight of a passenger pigeon and still later with her friend, Helen, searching for the mysterious Larkspur Lane. We watch her with Ned at Sylvan Lake and at a dance at the yacht club.

For the adventurous, this book has plenty of heart-thumping danger for Nancy at the old sanitorium, where she must try to rescue an elderly woman being held against her will by an evil Dr. Bull and his associates. With courage, tenacity and intelligence (and the help of her friend, Helen) Miss Drew risks her life for all of the women who have been conned by the con artists. Her determination to thwart these villanous, greedy people and bring them to justice makes this a truly satisfying book.

title: Some good observations
text:
Every now and again, there is something that I read that takes me back to the awkward balancing act that was high school and how much stress it was. The older you get, the memories fade and then you read something and it brings it back. When it was precise, that was the feeling that I got while reading Lindsey Lee Johnson's "The Most Dangerous Place on Earth" in that sense that actions, both careless and thoughtful, can have big repercussions.

The story takes place in a well-to-do town in California. It begins with eighth grade and we meet the students who who will make up the cast : Cally, Emma, Ryan, Abigail, Damon, Nick, Dave, Elizabeth and one more. It establishes their social world both in school and on social media. Social media being a point of connection and as a source of stress.

Then it goes to high school and their junior year. The group is older and in varying degrees, separated and together. Their lives intersect and diverge as is the way of high school. There is a new teacher, Molly, who becomes interested in her students that functions as a catalyst to observe and follow their stories over their junior and senior years.

As noted, when the story is good, it hits that uncomfortable spot of remembering the social stress of adolescence. The writer also seems to know the terrain of where the story takes place as the details have an authentic vibe. For me, it was cruising to a 4 star until it just started to load up on every single possible pitfall that a young person could fall into. Suicide, car accident, bullying, cheating, pedophile teacher, and so on. It lays it on thick which pushes it into soap opera rather than keen observation. It is still a good read but the pile-on of issues that the group faced seemed just one or two too many and affected the overall reading experience.

title: It's a beautiful story of a little boy who carries the challis ...

title: A stunning collection of perspective
text: Mr. Moyar provides proof positive that perspective often brings frigtening clarity.  Previous treatises on the Vietnam conflict have focused upon the final years of US involvement.  Few works have provided the necessary historical context as well as a sharp, critical analysis of our strategy.  The detailed references and superb sourcing reinforce what many scholars have been talking about around the edges of this time frame.  That the conflict was ours to lose is now no longer even remotely doubtful.  Serious students of military and political history would do well to take up this tome to refine their perspective of the second most socially / culturally defining conflict of the 20th century, the first being WWII.

title: This book is so thoughtfully put together!
text:
This book is so thoughtfully put together!
Now, I have to admit that I get nervous when it comes to books about "meditation" because they can get...well, a bit more out there then I'm interested in. But mindful meditation is such a different thing to me and I've found it so helpful. So I was really happy about this easy to follow book.
Each day has it's own short section, so it doesn't feel too overwhelming to tackle, but there are also some powerful questions to go over to help reflect on the new thing I tried that day.
For example, one part says to set a reminder to do mindful meditation 3 times a day and instantly I said "no way!!", but, I kept reading, and the way she broke the exercise down into these very short segments, it suddenly became something that was more manageable and very possible even on busy days.
It also makes you ask yourself the perfect questions for that particular exercise....some practice items I'd see and think "well duh!", but then, once I stopped and thought about it, I realized that I don't typically TRULY ask myself, or give myself permission to take the time for, some of these seemingly simple things, let alone take action to do anything positive about it. It seems easy but if you're really digging in, it's not that easy at first. But, say, on a subject that is a bit more difficult or intense for me personally (like all of chapter 2 and day 40 😊 ), I've been able to go even slower and take it small step by small step to get through it and came out with some new ways to help me deal with some of these issues in a positive way and I really appreciate that more then I can put into words here!

I'm told that in the printed copy of the book there are open blank spots by the reflection questions and other places, so you can have your notes right in the book which is awesome! But even if you get the Ebook, she has pages set up that have those questions on them. There is a link I clicked on right in the book at the end of the 'Commit to Yourself" section, right before day 1 begins. They are laid out really nicely and you can download them and print them out to have them for all your notes as well.

This book has been SO helpful to me and I am really enjoying putting it all to use.

title: Great trilogy!
text:
Closer to the Chest is the third and final book in The Herald-Spy trilogy, part of the Valdemar saga. I love Mags as a character; he’s one of my favorites in the entire saga of books.

In the other two books, the main conflict/intrigue was preemptive, stopping something before it could happen. The central conflict/intrigue of this book was different. In this one, they became embroiled in something already in progress. An unknown group was coming after the women of Haven, a group with a clear grudge against any woman who did not live their life in what that group believed was the proper way.

While I would have enjoyed a little more intrigue, as I like to be kept guessing, I loved the story of Mags and Amily as they sussed out the bad guys. What I appreciated the most was the message of the storyline, the place of women in the world. Because that was what was at the heart of the story… the place of women, the rights of women, bullying, victim-shaming. It’s a book, although released only five years ago, seems incredibly poignant in late of the times we live in.

However, I LOVED her precise use of language and her sarcastic thoughts and comments about others and society as a whole--that was refreshing! Not going to write a full book review...Amazon doesn't pay me to critique its offerings! (They should!) Despite the fact that this book caused me a little pain and anxiety, the plot evolved quite nicely and left one feeling hopeful...the resilience of the human spirit. Worth the read.

title: One Of The Best New 52 Relaunches
text:
Reprints Aquaman (2011 ongoing series) #s 1-6. To be honest, when I first started reading this book, I wasn't sure I was going to like it, but it won me over fairly quickly. Aquaman Volume 1: The Trench introduces the post-Flashpoint Aquaman, and as with a number of other DC titles launched that first month of the New 52 era, an awful lot of previous Aquaman canon was severely altered or even eliminated. So we're starting this corner of the DC Universe on a pretty fresh page. The existence of Aquaman has been known to the public for six years--much shorter than in the pre-Flashpoint continuity--and he seems to have gone public as a superhero about five years ago. (DC shrank the amount of time most of its central characters had been around, and also made nearly all of the lead characters look younger.) So how is Aquaman at the beginning of this new era? Well, it seems this charter member of the Justice League, lord of the seas, fierce fighter against evil, one of the more powerful super-beings on the planet is....an object of widespread public ridicule?

It seems DC has decided to respond to the naysayers (who I always ignored) who derided the character--"He's only there in case the Justice League needs to talk to a fish" and so on--by incorporating that sentiment into the world the character lives in. And if you've found the jokes at the Lord Of The Seven Seas's expense over the years irritating, you can only imagine how peeved Aquaman himself is about it. Early on Aquaman arrives on the scene of what appears to be a bank heist and puts a quick end to it before lives are put at risk...but not before being laughed at by the criminals he's about to stop. Then he's met with skepticism by the police he helped. This public sentiment about Aquaman isn't universal, but it's quite widespread. I didn't think this would work; it does though. As readers we see Aquaman as he really is, a top tier superhuman champion with a volatile temper he only barely holds in check. Many others see him differently. Early on thete's an air to the book that sooner or later something's going to happen, or Arthur's going to let his temper slip, and MAKE everybody stop laughing at him.

Even with having to put up with all of this, Aquaman's still got it pretty good. He's taken a leave of the ocean and Atlantis to try and make a life for himself on the surface world he grew up in, and he's got Mera with him. The press calls her Aquawoman; she appears to hate that name.

Troubles with public perception are going to be the least of the pair's worries though. Deep under the Atlantic Ocean, a long-sealed trench has opened up, and out come a horde of vicious semi-humanoid amphibious creatures (fantastic art on these) ravenous for food, including human meat. They swarm into the coastal town of Beachrock, a community close to the lighthouse Arthur and Mera are now using as a home. The battle takes place both on land and in and beneath the ocean, and the pair is left to make some very tough decisions very quickly. This is a consistent theme with the New 52 books: the heroes can't always save everybody, and the right thing to do is not always clear. What is clear is that this is a great launch into Aquaman's corner of the New 52 DC Universe. Recommended for both Aquaman fans and readers who've never read an issue of his, and all readers in between.

title: Tintin in America
text:
"Tintin in America" is the third Tintin adventure, originally a serial comic strip in the Belgian newspaper "Le Vingtième Siècle" from 1931-1932. It's not a Tintin adventure I'll reach for often, but it's all right.

It's 1931. After the events in "Tintin in the Congo", Tintin and his dog Snowy have been sent to Chicago to clean things up by way of an investigation into the criminal activity there. Al Capone wants him out of the way, while Capone's rival Bobby Smiles wants Tintin on his side. There's car chases, train chases, and even a scene or two in the Old West. Will Tintin "clean up", or will it all end up messier than before?

You can tell this was originally serialized, just by the way the action stops, starts and carries on. Lots of cliffhangers if you were reading it in in the newspaper back then. Could have gone anywhere, and that would have been interesting. Trouble is, as a whole story, the plot does seem a bit drawn out and rambling. There's a twist of satire in parts, though, which is interesting.

It's all right, but probably not the first Tintin adventure to pick up. "Secret of the Unicorn" might be a better start.

title: Excellent, practical, no-nonsense financial advice
text:
Liz Weston has a lot of calm, good advice for those who find themselves in debt. Rather than lose another night’s sleep, reading this book can reassure consumers that not all debt is bad. Her common sense approach, and the book’s layout makes it easy to navigate through various types of credit, loans and how to get them paid off and make the most of your financial planning.

For myself, because I went back to school later in life and racked up a bit of student debt, I was pacing the floor. Weston laid out the best strategies for someone like me to pay back the money owed. Using the principles in the book and paying off credit card debt first because of high interest rates and the like, I was happy to find I was in much better shape than I thought. While the advice is mostly common sense, the tone is really well worth the read. I highly recommend this book to college age students as well adults who have been at the financial game of life for a while.

title: Base story is great, needs edit
text:
I am fairly well versed in the atrocities that occurred in that area of the world at the time, as I followed it closely. And was shocked at some of the stories coming out of there. This book tells an unflinching story of that time, and illustrates the hate that can grow in people.

The main character is a peaceful farmer that enjoys life with his wife and daughter. Then the war begins and with the death of the wife and child of the farmer, blamed on his best friend (his brother), the farmer begins a brutal campaign of murder, rape and theft. He is constantly searching for his brother to get revenge, but never finds him...until the end. Then he sees, finally, how wrong he was.

The story is good but needs work, especially with the formatting. Dialog can be stilted (possibly because of the translation) and the characters are not well fleshed out. That said, there is a great book here.

I recommend this book highly.

title: A great suspenseful and paranormal read you won't be able to put down!
text:
Dark Passage is a gripping story and I finished it in one day! The story felt magnetic and I could not stop reading it! It is told from several different point of views and that was confusing to me at first, because I didn't know we had changed to a different character's POV. For future books, I think putting the character's name at the top of the page would help clear up that confusion. I really appreciated the different views from each character though, it really helped to round out the story.

Dark Passage is ultimately about good versus evil. A great battle is looming between the two sides. Which side will each character choose? This gripping story will have you uptight and maybe a bit anxious, until you finish the book! Will Jen be united with her soul mate and will good ultimately win over evil? The dark parts of this book were a bit dark for my taste. Reading about certain ritual sacrifices for the evil side were hard for me to stomach. However, they were not too descriptive, I am just more sensitive to violence than some people. That said, I was totally dumbfounded when the author dropped the "f-bomb" in the middle of the book. I felt it was completely out of place and not necessary to the story. For a book that discusses angels, God and the ultimate good, it seemed uncalled for. For those reasons I gave it four stars out of five. An overall great read, Dark Passage will not disappoint! I am anxious to see how things work out in the next book in the series!

UPDATE: Since posting my review the author has contacted me and informed me that the "f-bomb" has been taken out of both the Kindle version and the newest paperback version of the book!

I received this book for free.

title: Another fascinating sojourn in the Punktown universe
text:
Jeffrey Thomas' Blue War is a highly enjoyable novel that is hard to categorize as it blends a number of sub-genres into a thoroughly engaging whole. Being another of Thomas' Punktown stories, it has the urban-punk feel familiar to readers of China Mieville and William Gibson. And with the return of Jeremy Stake, the chameleon-like war veteran turned private investigator of his previous novel Deadstock, it has the gritty detective feel of Dashiell Hammet in a sci-fi setting. Add in a dose of a Michael Crichton cautionary techno-tale and you'll approach what there is to find in Blue War.

Chronologically, Blue War takes place shortly after the events of Deadstock and while Blue War could work as a stand-alone novel, it really works better if you've read Deadstock first. One of the things about Thomas' world of Punktown that makes it stand above others is that it - and the characters who inhabit it - all have history, and Thomas does a wonderful job of bringing this out in his descriptions:

"The men and women sheltering in the gloom of the Legion of Veterans' Post 69 ranged in age from early thirties to there-are-still-people-alive-from-that-war? The bartender was a veteran of the Red War, which had cost him an arm, replaced with a black prosthesis like something grafted on from a giant beetle. Watt was a Choom, one of the indigenous people of this planet, Oasis, though most of the Earth people in the colony city dubbed Punktown had been born here, too, as had their parents and even grandparents. To all appearances Watt was human, aside from the wide mouth carved back to his ears, giving his broad face a bit of a frog-like aspect. He was, however, rather more dangerous-looking than a frog.
--Seated in the post were a couple of Punktown servicemen who had been deployed to the world of Echo, part of a raid on the colony city of Oracle. A group of Red Jihad extremists had captured and sabotaged the atmosphere control facilities there, resulting in the death of 37,000 colonists. One of these vets, named Isaiah, cried a lot when he'd had a few Knickersons too many, recounting the numbers of suffocated children he had seen throughout the colony, strewn everywhere like placid-faced dolls.
--There were the brothers, Bobby and Wally, slouched over the bar in shiny blue jackets and faded baseball hats, all covered in glittering pins and embroidered patches indicating that they'd been crewmen aboard two military starcraft in the same fleet. They were withered and cantankerous and intent on claiming their explosive space battles made every other vet's war look like a picnic in the park. Gnome-like Bobby frequently came close to blows with younger vets, infantrymen bristling at the suggestion that their ground combat could be less hellish than what this old-timer had experienced from inside his massive warship. They always restrained themselves, however, having heard that his brother Wally had once smashed the jaw of a drunken vet twenty years younger than himself, in this very bar. Not to mention that Watt was quick to break up trouble, and that plastic beetle claw could grip you by the back of the neck good and hard on your way out the door.
--Two black men with shaved skulls, a branded insignia on their foreheads and metallic silver bar code on the back of their necks, had been coming in to sit at one end of the bar for a few months now. No one knew what war or conflict they'd been in, and they didn't volunteer it. Maybe Watt knew, but he was discreet. They spoke to no one, not even each other, just sipped their Zubs and watched the big VT screen mounted on the walls. Their polished domes reflected the blue of a holographic sign that read: 'Zub... for a mellow buz!' "

In this novel, Stake, a veteran of a war known as the Blue War that took place on an alien world called Sinan, a war that ended eleven years ago, is called on by an old army buddy who wants him to go back to Sinan to help solve a mystery that is threatening to unravel the peace that has held there for eleven years. A seemingly harmless Jin Haa urbanization project involving "smart matter" technology that allows a city to basically grow itself has gone wildly out of control, spilling across the border into Ha Jiin territory and swallowing up vast swathes of land. To make matters stranger still, the city has apparently created a living clone of a human, something it was not designed to do. Henderson needs Stake to try and find out what has gone wrong, and who this unknown clone child was made from, before war breaks out again. As as anyone who has read Deadstock will know, Stake himself has some unresolved history with his enemy/lover of his previous time on Sinan, the beautiful - and deadly - blue-skinned "Earth Killer", Thi Gonh.

One of the things I particularly like about Thomas' characters is that they are not black or white. They have their flaws, their baggage, and in many cases their conflicts, both in themselves and with others. All of which make them all the more real, and what happens to them will matter to the reader.

And as in Deadstock, there are a number of highly imaginative creations that are sprinkled throughout Blue War: benders (imagine Portugese Man-o-War's that can float through the air and kill you in ways you wouldn't wish on your worst enemy), snipes (no, these aren't imaginary though you'll wish they were if you run into them), rust art, Wonky Science, smart matter, and others.

All in all, Blue War works on a number of levels; quite an achievement for such an ambitious blending of genres. And, without giving anything away, one can only hope that there will be more, of Stake, of Thi, and of Punktown in general. Highly recommended.

title: Very Dark Comic Thriller That Occasionally Veers into Grand Guignol
text:
"Dr. Fischer of Geneva,"(1980), was, I believe the 25th novel published by widely-known and respected British author Graham Greene in his very long career that spanned most of the 20th century. It is one of his last published novels, and is a 150 page, novella length, very dark comic thriller.

It is narrated by Alfred Jones, child of a knight in the British Foreign Service, who has fallen very far socially and economically from the class into which he was born. He does, however, have that proficiency in languages so useful to the Foreign Service, and lives and works in Switzerland, as a translator at a firm that produces that characteristic Swiss product, chocolate. Jones, who lost both his left hand and his parents in the same night's World War II German bombardment of London, has married Anna-Luise, Fischer's beautiful heiress daughter, who is, furthermore, much his junior. He comes to discover he hates his father-in-law, a powerful multi-millionaire who made his fortune by inventing Dentophil Bouquet, a supposedly more effective toothpaste. Although, to be sure, the author Greene, who never lost his eye for the telling detail, has Anna-Luise tell Jones that her father doesn't use his own product: he instead uses, she says, "Something called a Water-Pik."Go know that Water-Piks were even available thirty years ago.

At any rate, Dr. Fischer is known for his dinner parties, at which he debases and humiliates other rich people, his so-called "friends," whom his daughter calls "toads." His guests apparently are so greedy for the lavish gifts which their host--for whom they do not really care-- will ultimately present them that they will swallow any treatment he dishes out, up to and including possible death.

Like most of Greene's prodigious output, this novel was filmed, as an all-star television production. It was directed by Michael Lindsay-Hogg, starred James Mason as Dr. Fischer, Alan Bates as Alfred Jones, Greta Scacchi as Anna-Luise, and Cyril Cusack as Steiner, a companion music lover of Anna-Luise's late mother.

Graham Greene (1904-1991) was one of the most illustrious British writers of the 20th century. He enjoyed a very long life, most of the century, and a very long, prolific writing career, during which he gave us THE POWER AND THE GLORY, THE END OF THE AFFAIR, and OUR MAN IN HAVANA, among many others. Many, if not most, of his works were made into notable films.

The author's books were very well-written, highly literate; much praised by the critics, and enjoyed a wide readership; they were frequently best sellers. The writer was also one of the better-known Catholic converts of his time; many of his thrillers deal with Catholic themes of guilt and redemption. Greene, who also worked as a screenwriter, always created a tight thriller, in a lean, realistic style that boasted almost cinematic visuals. However, if you've never read him before, I wouldn't necessarily recommend starting here. It's black-on-black, occasionally veering into Grand Guignol, to which I must admit I didn't know quite how to respond. It's also hard to find. Might as well start with something more entertaining, like THE COMEDIANS, or TRAVELS WITH MY AUNT.

title: Another Pointless Self-Help Book
text:
I'm not sure why I ordered this book other than that it was free. I am not the type of person who reads self-help or business books and the one or two times in my life that I was forced to do so I couldn't see the point of the book nor did I derive anything beneficial. I have been in sales most of my life and at various points have been known as one of the top salesmen in my field. I've often been asked to share what has made me successful so I have taught classes on selling. It seems to me to be an exercise in futility. I wish it was easy to simply tell some one how to be or what to do and that success will follow. It is my belief that human beings are infinitely more complex than what the business & self-help books portray and they do not change easily, if ever. I am sure that there are people who have benefitted from this class of book but I have never met one and I suspect they are rare. People are what they are and even if you get them excited for a short time they soon revert to their norm.

As far as this book goes it seems neither better nor worse than other books in its class. It relies on telling stories to show people how they might use different behaviours to achieve more influence. I don't think reading this book is going to enable anyone to make a profound change in their lives, just as the past twenty years worth of self-help and business books haven't seemed to make a bit of difference to anyone I know personally or within society in general. There is an old saying, "Those who can, do, those who can't, teach". That's why I don't teach anymore. It's depressing to try and teach something and see that the message sent just isn't ever received because of the fundamental difference in experience, motivation, outlook and thought processes between two different people. I would also offer this thought....the only way you'll change your life or influence others successfully is simply to go try doing it and get better. In other words, there is no magic words/spell/book that is going to change your world. There is only doing, practice, and gaining experience. Save your time and money, skip the book, and go practice influencing others. You'll fail a lot, but then you get better incrementally, and you'll have made progress. It's as unlikely that you'll make progress reading a book as it is unlikely that you'll learn to play the piano by reading a book. People make a lot of money by the lure of a shortcut to be found within the pages of their book but I don't know of any shortcuts to playing a piano or in learning to influence others. I sure didn't see any in this book.

title: Reverse Marketing:  Purchasing's Greatest Strategy
text: This book is a timeless classic.  It describes a simple, 12-point method for Purchasing to organize, present and negotiate a strategic proposal to your SUPPLIERS.  This is just backwards compared to common business  practice; but it is very innovative and is well founded in common sense.  Leenders and Blenkhorn, professors from Portland State University (at the  time), offer several good case studies from firms who have used this  methodology.  It is applicable to firms in all businesses.  This  methodology should be taught to all senior executives of manufacturing and  distribution businesses in North America.  If that was so, we would have  excellent supplier relations and fewer suppliers to deal with.  We could  also control our materials costs a lot better than today. A good read.  Give it a shot.  It will pay for itself many times over.

title: Salivating, humorous, informative, fun
text:
The naysayers miss the point. She could (easily) have written a traditional cookbook with tons of recipes no one will ever attempt but instead, she chose practical. We are the storytelling species and this a collection of hers. Thankfully we get no moralizing over sustainability, environmental preaching, diet of the day boosting or wagging fingers at human habits. Instead we find beautiful writing - something sorely missing in the food world today. This is NOT like the juvenile tv shows with their endless silly contests or those idiot cookbooks of Three steps, Four ingredients, Five minutes or 300 calories. It is not "My 300,000 best Fall recipes for those who hate to cook". It is instead a reverie on food, taste and cooking.

Vivian's books are literary and culinary gems - a rarity. Many reviewers, in the raving for a traditional cookbook, miss the humor found throughout. Her "poses" for each chapter say it all - Molly the Riveter, Stabbing a tomato, busy at her desk for the aptly named "Community Organizer". She reveals her motivations, failures, successes, what is passable, good and great. In this case, ordinary are transformed into something new and delicious through nine "concoctions" that are simultaneously interesting, basic and delicious. My Grade = A+

She assigns cute names like Citrus Shrine, Little Green Dress, Community Organizer, etc - you get the point. Following each introductory story and reipe for the helpers is a list of recipes (with accompanying dialogue and great food porn) using the mixtures. I found it best suited for summer when herbs are fresh and fruit and veggies are at their peak and you can make lots for friends. Some can be preserved as little treats / ice cubes that will get us throught the darkness and cold of winter.

My Grade: A+

title: Here's An Idea for the Next Boring Dinner Party you May Attend...
text:
Well, this is a most peculiar book, very surprising and ingenious, quite different from anything you are likely to have read in the recent past or in the near future for that matter. Even the title leaves you thinking something is a bit odd...

The very meandering plot revolves around Miles Garth, an ethical consultant, somewhere in his forties, who, one night at a dinner party in Greenwich, gets up between courses, makes his way upstairs to the spare room and locks himself in. Indefinitely. You would probably get up and isolate yourself too if you were at a dinner party with guests such as were at this dinner party. Nevertheless we never find out why he takes this course of action, in fact the reason, whatever it may be, has no bearing at all on how the story unfolds. Almost overnight Miles becomes a cause celebre, with people camping out in the street to catch a glimpse of him, organising a food delivery by basket and rope (he is vegetarian and the owner of the house he refuses to leave only feeds him slim slices of ham slid under the door), and media swarming as media does.

Four people, closely and loosely associated with Miles narrate the four chapters - There, But, For, The. Anna met Miles on a bus tour of Europe some 20 years prior; Mark is Miles' boyfriend and had taken Miles with him to the dinner party; May is an elderly lady biding time and hating it in a rest home; and Brooke is a nine year old girl, highly intelligent, lively, bordering on precocious and loving it. There are other people too on the periphery such as the other dinner party guests, Mark's long time boyfriend, May's husband and Brooke's parents as well as Jen, the dinner party hostess.

The message or theme of this book? Not entirely sure, but feel it has something to do with No Man Is An Island, or maybe he is, and one state or the other is neither a bad thing or a good thing. Confused?

So we play a bit loose with the point of the book but the real pleasure of this book, what stopped me from putting it down and thinking all a bit too odd really, is the writing. It is an absolute joy to read because Ms Smith is a master of words - puns galore (Brooke LOVES puns); witty clever dialogue used in such a way that the character of the speaker is revealed without us really knowing anything about them - the dinner party is fantastic reading (I read it twice); enlightening discussions about the word 'But' for example. Brooke is truly delightful, she would be an impossible child to have in a classroom, but her observations of the adults around her, her passionate interest in her home town of Greenwich as the place that Western time is measured from, (read symbolism for the time passing in the lives of the characters) marks her out as quite the most interesting character in the book.

The whole thing is really quite genius, I just loved her use of language, it dances all over and it all contributed to the package of what is quite an unusual book, but all in a good way. Even if I am not quite sure of its raison d'etre.

title: The First Hero of Greek Mythology
text:
The story of Jason and the Argonauts is one of the oldest heroic stories of Western Civilization. Homer makes reference to Jason in both the Iliad and the Odyssey. However, the first complete telling of the myth comes to us from the Third Century BCE in the epic poem, Argonautica. "Jason and the Glden Fleece" is a retelling of the Argonautica with children as its targeted audience.

"Jason and the Golden Fleece" does a good job of tracking the plot line of the Argonautica. All the major characters and incidents are included in this version. The writing is competent and the illustrations are first class. However, what keeps me from giving this book five stars is that I am not sure the Argonautica can really be condensed for children. It is too interesting a story to be reduced down to its simplest plot elements. Although I have not read it, I suspect that the Padraic Colum and Willy Pagany retelling probably does the myth more justice.

Thank you for putting this inspiring book together, what a tribute to these artists, especially the one who was so hurt - my heart goes out to him & his family for what he went through.  And my hat's off to the author for acknowledging him.  I recommend everyone get this book if you are interested in caricatures and how they're created.  To go from an ordinary picture to what they came up with is mind-boggling.  WOW........

title: D L Cooper tells a wonderful story full of unexpected twists and turns!
text:
D L Cooper tells a wonderful story full of unexpected twists and turns. It takes place in various locations, including the beautiful waters of the Chesapeake Bay and Virgin Islands, areas Cooper has obviously sailed. His passion for sailing comes through in his writing, although this is a novel that can be enjoyed by sailors and non-sailors alike because of its rich character development and great action scenes.

Cooper’s style is reminiscent of the Robert B. Parker Spenser novels and John D. McDonald Travis McGee series with his flair for storytelling and a strong, yet vulnerable male in the lead role. By the time you finish the book, you will feel Phillip is an old friend who has taken you on a thrilling ride. It is full of intrigue, suspense, adventure, international politics, romance, sex, and imagination, all elements for a great read. "Converging Courses" will have you looking forward to reading more by this remarkable author.

title: Reads like a Korean "Lonesome Dove"
text: I am always ready to lose myself in historical fiction but I never thought that a book that takes place so recently would fascinate me. We know of Korea as a divided country that is so poor in the North that people scrounge in public parks for flowering buds or even pigeons to eat because of the constant prospect of starvation. By contrast, in the South we have corporations like Samsung and KIA who sell their products in the United States. Many of us have family in the military who have spent time in South Korea. The Korea in "Tendrils of Life" is a post World War 2 country reeling from years of Japanese rule and then the occupation of United Nations troops with the United States calling the shots because they defeated Japan.  A family is brought back to the mainland of South Korea after an idyllic life on an isolated island. The father seems to be a passionate follower of causes that will bring justice to the land. Of course he earns the emnity of some friends he grew up with as well as relatives. His family suffers, living hand to mouth in Seoul while the father is gone. The son,Jimin, takes menial jobs before school to help feed his mother and sister. He begins to have a lifelong resentment of his father but because the father is in jail or in hiding much of the time, he cannot express it to him. The war comes to not only the cities but the countryside and the family finds themselves being torn apart and reunited with each other and former friends. Jimin wishes so much to return to the island of his youth but he wants his family with him  and it seems that there is always a band of soldiers, bandits or physical barriers keeping him from his family. This is a roller coaster and I had to stay with it because I was so invested in the characters that I finished it very quickly. I found that the pages explaining the history of Korea and the conditions of the time to be educational as well as helpful.

title: Excruciatingly good; filled with symbolism
text:
Cecelia Ekbäck's writing is spare and evocative, with an unerring instinct for presentation of character flaws and natural human fears. Wolf Winter is filled with beautifully handled symbolism - the church bells whose sounds bedevil a priest with a secret, plus I especially enjoyed "crayfish" for carcinoma, a delightful use of metonymy - and the supernatural elements are maybe, maybe not, which is to say that they could be a dead man stalking or they could be the product of fear in the everlasting night. Or mental derangement.

The author takes us 'way north to Lapland where a few settlers dare live in the shadow and seemingly malevolent influence of Blackåsen, the mountain that takes the blame for the actions of men. She weaves into the story Swedish political history as well as social: the juxtaposition of old superstitions and the Christianity that forbids (or replaces) them. She writes, via story narrative, a powerful treatise about the role of guilty secrets and false accusations which in a small, righteous population cause the accused to be painfully, even fatally shunned and punished by church or law, the same thing in days of yore.

This novel deserves a prize.

title: Fawlty Memoir
text:
John Cleese's memoir here is quite amusing and especially interesting for his comments on comedy.

Unfortunately, he ultimately gives rather short shrift to the two pieces of work for which he's best known -- "Monty Python's Flying Circus" and "Fawlty Towers."

Though Cleese spends much of the book discussing his earlier comedic efforts in great detail, when he gets to "Python," he focuses mostly on the stage show reunion a few years back -- an endeavor, he freely admits, to help the aging Pythons restore their chestnut stashes to see them into a comfortable retirement.

He writes a bit about the way the group members worked together putting together the famous show, but there's precious little detail about how they developed some of the most celebrated sketches back in the day.

As for "Fawlty Towers" -- I don't recall him saying a word about this exalted gem of a farce. Nothing on the writing, casting, acting, or directing.

So I for one hope John will confer with his analyst to determine why he overlooked these highlights of his career in assembling this memoir -- and that he will address the missing sections in much greater detail in an amended edition.

text:
This series continues to get better! One thing I would advise upfront: read in order, because the happenings in this book made it necessary to give spoilers about the first book. I'm loving these regular characters even more. Just like the first, this book was full of intrigue, secrets and even some con artists tossed in for good measure. I can't really say a whole lot, since I don't want to give anything away, but this was definitely a good Halloween read due to the Halloween party held at Merry's castle. I could just picture her spooky but elegant decor that she wanted to be sure wasn't too hokey or overdone.

I'm happy that Merry realized that her husband who'd died eight years ago wouldn't want her to be mourning and thinking about no one but him. She did let herself go and had some thoughts about handsome sheriff Virgil. I'm anxious to see that friendship develop into something nice. And sweet Pish who was always like a father to her was still there and had a great idea for bringing in more income after Merry got a very lucrative offer not to buy the castle but to make some income. title: A Historical Crime Drama
text:
This is my first Colson Whitehead novel. I have a number of his books on my TBR but I always tend to put off reading books that are what I put in the category of "heavier novels". However, this one was a great balance.

This book chronicles the life of a business owning black man in 60's era Harlem. Ray Carney comes from a crooked family. Raised by his father who was a known crook. As an adult, Ray went to college and got his business degree and now owns a furniture store. He's legit and provides for his wife and 2 children. Even he if does meddle in products that were acquired by less than honest means. He's only "a little crooked". There is also a heist of a prominent Harlem hotel that Carney is pulled into by his cousin Freddy, that doesn't go all that smoothly.

I loved Whitehead's writing. There were points in the book that fell flat and made me a little bored but they were easy to get through due to the beautiful writing. This book chronicles what is was like in 60's Harlem as a black man, an entrepreneur, and as a crook. The characters are all interesting and there's even some humor that if you don't pay attention, you could miss. I am very excited to read his other books now that I've dipped my toes. I recommend this for those that enjoy a good crime book and historical fiction.

Thank you Netgalley and Double day for providing an eARC for an honest review.

title: NOT...  for learning how to program your IPAD, IPOD, IPhone and fancy home gadgets.....goes deeper..
text:
My first impression of Electronics Explained is that I would learn the layman's instructions to electronics, you know the fancy gizmos and gadgets that are increasingly infiltrating life. But to my surprise, this book goes a lot deeper. I was positive you had to be an electrical engineer in order to understand the dynamics of the book. After some closer reading, I have determined that it is not all that difficult to understand.

And, I am sure with a deeper and closer approach to the content of the book, one can come away with some selective knowledge.

Chapter Setup is easy to navigate throughout; each chapter with a bullet list identifies what you are to expect, plus there is an easy to understand introduction to each chapter.

List of Figures. It is not often that a book has a listing and page number of each of the Figures in the book. The book contains about 150 Figures, and the reader can locate specific ones easily. Also, each Figure demonstration is easy to read, clearly identified, and very well labeled.

Projects. One good thing about the information is that the author gives the reader something to do, something to try on his own. The Projects sections are easily identified.

Page Layout. This is not a high book, but it is in black and white, plenty of whitespace surrounds the pages, Topics are clearly identified in Bold Font. Diagrams, charts, demos, whatever are well spaced, nothing is crowded and easy to read the print.

Again, do not get this book if you can't figure how your IPAD or IPOD work. But what you will learn is the concept of electronics, principles that formt he basis of electronics. Here is an idea of some of the topics you will learn about; Electronics - atoms, charge, conductors, magnetism, voltage sources, systems, linear circuits, binary, how microcomputers work, wireless, satellites, audio electronics, digital, video tech, cable, etc., etc.

Again, the average person, like me, will not understand the majority of this book, but you will always get something out of it. Those who understand the tech of electronics, especially, in this electronic age, will understand much more than me. Excellent book, great reference! Rizzo.

title: Good reading even for a youngish adult
text:
Sequel to Melissa Marr's Wicked Lovely Fragile Eternity reacquaints us with Seth, Ash and Keenar as they struggle with the consequences of the previous novel's conclusion. Ash plays the reluctant immortal, Seth deals with the devil to be with Ash, and Keenar continues with his romantic pursuit of Ash.

Risking a cheesy Twilight rip-off, Fragile Eternity does quite well (as predicted in my review of Ink Exchange I might add.) The characters seem genuine and 3-d and the plot flows without becoming mired in drippy romantic dialogue.

There are a couple of flaws. First is an issue I have with many urban fantasy novels, which is that they play too much as a series, as in far too much page time is given to build up for cataclysmic future events, can either lead to tension being defused somewhat over the story, and/or disappointment in the end when some issues are left unresolved.

Second is Marr's supernatural imagery. What is quite a cool idea- The faerie folk having elemental effects on the environment around then, and War in particular having strange-bird like features- is somewhat diminished by the clipped and plain prose used to describe them. I imagine it would all look awesome on the big screen, but in a novel reader's need a little more descriptive writing, perhaps and appeal to senses other than sight (for example if ice is forming on the walls, shouldn't the characters feel cold?)

A prior flaw that is less evident in this novel is the overuse of Faerie politics and practice carrying the plot. Most of what goes on in Fragile eternity is easy to follow, and interesting. Marr's series is definitely worth a read, as going by my theories each following book will be better than the last, by the forth we could have a sure best-seller.

title: Hardboiled pastoral
text:
Published shortly before the author's suicide in 1950, after an affair with an American actress, the hardboiled nature of Cesare Pavese's final novel demonstrates his skill, honed by translations of American literature, in integrating the hardboiled prose style or Chandler, Cain, and Hemingway back into Italian. Or vice versa, as R.W. Flint's rendering in turn of Pavese emphasizes its affinities. I am reminded of how Hemingway tried to convey Spanish idioms or Italian landscapes in his own fiction, so Pavese's familiar tone, for American readers in this 2002 edition for New York Review Classics, should find a ready reception among those curious to see how an Italian enamored of American sensibilities tries to work them into his own language, and his own post-war, pastoral sensibilities.

The results, to me, are modest but successful on these terms. Mark Rudman's introduction might be read as an afterward, for he gives away the whole plot and its climactic scene. However, Pavese's decision to treat that as the final two pages of his novel, and to cut away from any lasting denouement, attests to his skill, and daring.

Other writers would have softened this or pressed it into a framework more pliable. It's true that for long stretches of this 150-page novel, not much happens, on the other hand, so the action that does occur, told in retrospect, does matter more. I was not as pulled into the narrative as I expected. Perhaps as a Californian, viewing the remove at which Oakland, Fresno, the great valleys, and the desert of this state are evoked in a stylized manner (reminding me of the rather endearing way Kafka imagined his Amerika) kept me distanced. I was not convinced by the narrator's loves or adventures, for these--nodding back to the tough-guy inspirations--are not given enough depth to draw you close.

However, in the smells of Italy's lime trees, the legend of how the moon fructifies the fields if bonfires are set at its margins, and how as in 1914, so since: war is "a lot of dogs unchained by their masters to murder each other and keep their masters in control" (88), there is enough to satisfy a reader. "Maybe it is better that way, better for everything to go up in a bonfire of dry grass and for people to begin again. That was how it was in America--when you were sick of something, a job or a place, you changed it. Over there even whole towns, with taverns, city halls and stores, are as empty now as graveyards." (120-1) This sparely told narrative leaves its impression, in a muted, melancholic manner. Not the lively evocation of the war against the Fascists I had suspected, Pavese prefers to tamp down the emotion, and to use memory and equivocation to explore his national pain.

title: Teenage Sydney Bristow from Alias meets X-Men`s Mystique w/ a couple significant weaknesses
text:
IMPOSTOR, the first book in Suzanne Winnacker's Variant series, is kind of like a teenage Sydney Bristow from Alias meets X-Men`s Mystique. Tessa has been recruited to the FEA (Forces with Extraordinary Abilities) branch of the FBI. She's been training for two years and honing her chameleon-like ability to take on the appearance of anyone she touches. At sixteen she gets her first mission tracking a serial killer.

The premise is really strong and the investigation takes a number of cool turns, not the least of which is the whole Variant concept which includes all kinds of abilities from invisibility to mind reading. The Variant idea isn't groundbreaking, nor is Veronica Mars-esque teen investigator, but what made IMPOSTOR work was the mystery/thriller plot which, apart from an uneven start, kept me guessing and engaged until the very end.

While the story and concept were solid, there were a couple significant weaknesses. The writing isn't quite as good as I was hoping. It's very melodramatic, and the pacing was rushed. And Tessa as a character was really immature for someone in her situation. She was thoughtless and childish and realistically would never have been given as much control in a HUGE investigation based on her behavior. Which brings me to my second gripe with this book: the romance. It never came close to working for me. Alec, Tessa's slightly older trainer, is her longtime crush. He's got a girlfriend (who is a catty, vicious, witch-but a great guy like Alec is still into her), but he still has cuddling movie dates with Tessa and tons of almost-kissing moments. It made no sense that he would be interested in a girl as immature as Tessa despite their shared love of horror films.

Despite the flaws, the strength of the story carried me easily to the very last page of IMPOSTOR. Hopefully, Tessa will grow by the next book in the Variant series since I'd kinda like to see where her story goes.

Sexual content:
Kissing. References to sex.

title: philosphical, ethical, and in the end human
text:
When Breath Becomes Air
by Paul Kalanithi

As a NYT best seller with over 11,000 reviews on Amazon-- much has been said  about this deeply philosophical book wherein a Nuerosurgeon and literary aficionado gives us an ethical and  moral run down of his decisions to train as a doctor responsible for decisions (and millimeters of difference under the knife) that affect brains and thus our very identities....and then learns of a cancer diagnosis and must rexamine all those choices in the light if impending death.

Far more erudite folks than I have commented on his thoughtful words and ideas about medical care.

What i can provide, is my own perspective as  someone who has faced cancer, as Paul did, as  well as the difficult decisions (that you are never sure have been made correctly) about treatment and the acceptance of irrevocable change and damage that comes along with treatment.

Like Paul, I have passed my first round. I don't know if, like Paul, I will face another round that will ultimately be the reason for my death.

I do know, that like Paul, a consequence of having faced a cancer diagnosis is, even for someone like me who is not an ambitious doctor with much lower stress commitments, something that has caused me in a teeth-grindingly obvious cliche to want my energy spent in pursuit of the contentment one finds through family and friends and rejection of the urges society dictates in favor of things that create connection.

Paul writes to his daughter Cady not to discount the joy she brought him, dying, as she lay on his lap: a little piece of the ever present now a parent can not deny or put off or fake.

And while my own children were not of lap age during my diagnosis, and I am facing the loss of my own identity as their parent as they enter the high school years just before leaving home, I do believe that the best of all possible results of living through cancer treatment and the resulting lifetime of uncertainty is to live contentedly. 

So if reading this book (along with Atul Gawande's Being Mortal) makes me a bit maudlin and cliche..so be it. These are two books I believe all should read. An easy path to thinking about death...a crutch, if you will, as you follow along the authors' thoughts towards the end, inevitably you will consider your own.

title: ... mother and recorded her life story - one of great hardships, perseverance
text:
Veronica Li sat down with her mother and recorded her life story - one of great hardships, perseverance, and the occasional triumph - after discovering that her mother dreamed of writing. Instead of regular chapter numbers, the chapters are listed as "tape 1", "tape 2", etc to reflect this.

Her mother weaves a tale that began before World War 2 and continues to her move to America in the 1960's from China. She braves childhood poverty, a harsh mother, a father's death, disease, and war to achieve an education for herself and her own children.

While I admire her pertinacity and felt compelled to read the whole book, I felt that the chapters were a bit long making finding good stopping points a little difficult. But, the story is coherent and easy to follow.

I did learn about China's recent political history and how impacted the culture. I also enjoyed her vivid descriptions. For example, at one point, the author describes a man that is a "wrinkled man who looked like a piece of laundry that had shrunk in hot water."

Be sure to stick around for that author's epilogue to find out what happened with her parents!

title: Perfect for Christmas

title: A nice guide with some clever ideas
text:
This is an interesting and useful guide to using various materials you have left over from crafting or sewing projects, items you have in your home such as soda cans, tin cans, plastic packaging, etc. in your craft projects.

This guide is quite useful for the person new to "upcycling" who may not know exactly what to even look for on the internet when wanting some quick ideas. This guide is also very useful for the ability to use it when internet access is not available (yes, believe it or not, that still happens sometimes!). I especially appreciated the information about different die-cutting dies that she had specifically tested in order to cut different materials, because I don't necessarily want to ruin half my dies by trying to cut something they can't cut, but neither do I want to have dies and embossing folders that I don't use because I am afraid of messing them up, when I could be making fantastic creations out of them. I also appreciated some of the ideas I had not thought of, such as layering or blending colors of spray paint on clear plastic to achieve different effects.

This is a basic guide. It has a few techniques that are very suited to the beginning or novice crafter, or the crafter who is new to die cutting/embossing or mixed-media techniques. For especially experienced crafters, it might not be the most useful thing. I have to say, though, I consider myself an expert crafter, but even I got some new ideas from this guide! In fact, I have done some of the projects she did in a slightly different way - I will be chatting with her about exchanging ideas, which is one of the greatest things about crafting!

I recommend this book for anyone who enjoys crafting, and especially for anyone who is interested in using up all of their materials, finding a way to incorporate new and unexpected elements into their work, or who enjoys die-cutting/embossing, card-making, or creating mixed-media projects. I think it is a good value for the price for this use.

bottom line? recommended for ALL ages. VERY good book.

I knocked off one star because there were some typographical errors that careful editing would have fixed, and she has a nice gallery of photographs that I wish had captions.

Disclaimer: I received a copy of this e-book free in exchange for my honest opinion, which I have given here.

title: Not quite
text:
The Tierney family needed a change. Caroline was been suffering from depression, Ben's newest novel was going nowhere, and older son Charlie was being bullied at school.In an attempt to get a new start, the family moves to a remote village in upstate New York with plans to renovate an old mansion and turn it into an inn. At first the change seems to be doing everyone good. Ben starts a new book, Caroline is busy with the house and kids, and their son Charlie seems to love exploring the outdoors. The idyllic life doesn't last long though as things quickly go from bad to worse.

This book tries hard to be an Amityville Horror, Children of the Corn, spooky, conspiracy-type horror story, but it doesn't quite make it. First of all, the story moves way too slow and Ben takes way to long to notice something's going on. I also don't think the multiple change in POV worked for this book. We never got close to any one character--and really never cared about any of them either. And the reasoning for the whole thing was really never quite made clear--at least not in a way that made sense for the characters to do what they did. I think this writer has potential--maybe a few more rewrites could have honed this into a really good horror story--it just wasn't quite there yet.

title: Shaved time off this newbie's 500m swim / Why you should purchase this book
text:
I started swimming laps a year ago. My 500 was a splashy 15 minute fight with 25 meters of water in my way each direction. I joined a group of triathletes in the pool and got some much needed direction on my stroke. 500m went down to 12. Months went by, a couple months I even gave up swimming altogether as I was quite discouraged. Then I was possessed once more by the lore of the water (and bikini season). I purchased this book about two weeks ago, started thinking about the concepts presented in it during my workouts and hit a 9 minute 500m yesterday that didn't leave me completely wasted on the pool wall.
The only con for me was his repetitive writing style. He tends to reiterate a lot...just be ready to read like you should swim-slice through it, don't fight it.
Might not be a competitive swimmer's time, but it's something I'm very proud of. I strongly recommend this book (investment) to anyone looking for other ways to improve their water confidence for just a few bucks. Looking forward to a great triathlon season!

title: An Academic's Look at Sasquatch
text:
Considered one of the original “four horsemen” and the only one to have full academic qualifications, Dr. Grover S. Krantz is one of the most important figures in the search for a native North American ape. Bigfoot Sasquatch Evidence: The Anthropologist Speaks Out is Grover S. Krantz looking at the evidence he’s studied since 1965 to conclude that there is a nonhuman bipedal in North America.

Originally published in 1992 and republished with an addendum in 1999, Krantz looked at the evidence supporting the existence of Sasquatch in the first two-thirds of the original book from looking at the footprint evidence and then analyzing the Patterson-Gimlin film subject and all the evidence pointing to its authenticity of a real animal. The final third of the original text was Krantz looking at evidence of other unknown bipedal animals from around the world and examining those researching Sasquatch. Three academic articles that Krantz wrote were added at the end of the original book followed by the 1999 addendum that Krantz addressed major and minor developments but doing so by following chapter title of the original edition and inserting information there thus giving these added pages a nice structure. Overall Krantz is an academic writer and while he gets the information across his style is boring—he is not a Jeff Meldrum, who is referenced a lot in the addendum, that can be academic for the general reader—however that doesn’t mean that the book is bad just not amazing.

Bigfoot Sasquatch Evidence is an academic’s look into the possibility of a bipedal ape in North America, Dr. Grover S. Krantz is a thorough writer though very lively in his delivery.
