title: It was just....OK!
text:
If you are a Patterson Lover, and have not grown tired of the "I am Alex Cross and all my friends are either crazed killers who I am tracking and don't know it...or I have a ton of problems and yet still manage to solve the crime"...this tale is for you. After a much needed break [I had decided that I needed to give Alex Cross a little rest and enjoy some of Patterson's other works,like the winged people....now that was interesting and I enjoyed it] I picked up in the series where I left off....Big Bad Wolf. Unfortunately, after reading it I felt a little out of sorts and had to ask myself the question..."just what do I think of this novel?" I really had to search within myself and decide what was it that I just didn't get? Or is it that I got it, but wasn't sure if I liked it?

Well for starters we still have the ever present Alex Cross, who has left the DC PD and decided to go Federal (FBI);then there's "Mama Nana" or whatever he calls his mother, who quietly states the obvious;his friend, Sampson who makes a cameo appearance and states that he is expecting a child; his absent girlfriend (Jamilla) who appears to be a little too mysterious for my taste at first, but appears periodically throughout the thriller (encouraging phone calls no less, hope she doesn't turn out to be a killer); Kyle (his psychotic ex-friend who use to work for the FBI); and a few others. Patterson also introduces new characters, like Monty (FBI computer expert, single with kids) and Mahoney (an eager partner who loves the excitement of having a partner who is willing to think out of the box....so I am sure he will either ultimately be killed or be the crooked FBI agent that is being paid off by the Wolf). Unfortunately, most of my rating is based solely on the love I have for Patterson's creativity and not so much about my love of the book. Although there was A LOT of potential (I loved the mystery surrounding who the Wolf really is) it was a little confusing. Patterson spent the first have of the novel introducing a sadistic, kidnapping couple and killed them early on. He introduced a concept of white slavery among the rich...which was interesting, but then it seemed forced by introducing so many other "bad things" that the wolf was involved in....it just all seemed a little FORCED. Oh and another thing, because I am not in love with the character of Alex's baby's mother, Christine, I did not enjoy her reappearance after being absent for over a year. I didn't care about her as a character and wondered why she was coming back. It just seemed that while Alex was trying to solve his first case while joining the FBI, he just didn't need the drama surrounding his exgirlfriend's decision to claim their son. Of course I know, and you will too when and if you complete it, that the whole book is set up for the sequel, but I am not sure that I want to read it. OK, I probably will!

title: Quick, easy read
text: Despite all the odds, the reader hopes for the best. This story minimizes the legal work and highlights a faulty legal system. None, other than our heroine, believes the underdog.

title: A personal political diatribe or a relevant medical-political thriller? You decide.
text:
Michael Palmer died unexpectedly a few months ago in October of 2013. “Resistant” is the author’s twentieth and final novel. It stands alone, but it’s the third book in the author’s Dr. Lou Welcome series. The novel was complete and at the publisher before he died.

I was curious to read his final novel. In the past, I’d enjoyed the rich medical details, tight plotting, suspense, and intrigue of his earlier works. The author’s untimely death saddened me and reawakened my interest in his work. I was curious how his writing might have changed over the years. I knew that he was a skilled commercial storyteller of unapologetically formulaic medical thrillers. It was a genre that has always held my interest, but lately, there seemed to be so many new and talented writers in this arena, I had no time or interest to return to Michael Palmer. Not until now.

What I discovered immediately about this Lou Welcome series is that the author had branched out into a crossover genre half way between political and medical thrillers. The novel is still packed with his signature, testosterone-filled action, suspense and medical detail, but there is a major controversial political issue at its core. It’s the same issue that’s currently dividing our Nation. If you’re on the liberal side of this issue, this book may please you. If you’re on the conservative side, it will probably make you angry. Whatever side you’re on, I’m sure you’ll recognize that the politics at its core is a gross distortion that adds nothing to the political debate.

“Resistant” is about a small clandestine group of ultra-fanatic right-wing conservatives. They call themselves the Society of One Hundred Neighbors. They came into existence in the era of FDR and Ayn Rand. Currently, they exist to rid the United States of all entitlement programs (especially Social Security, Medicare, and Medicaid) and free the country from what they see as the death grip of bankrupting debt. They’re prepared to go to any ends necessary to achieve their goal, including biological terrorism. Their new weapon is the Janus bacterium, a germ very similar to streptococcus pyogens, the flesh-eating bacteria that causes necrotizing fasciitis. They’ve unleashed the pathogen in target hospitals around the country. The government is managing the crisis in secret to contain public panic. The government calls the terrorist weapon the Doomsday Germ. The trouble is, the bacteria have gotten the upper hand. They’re mutating. The Society’s new antibiotic agent can no longer contain them.

So how does the author’s main character, Dr. Lou Welcome, get involved in the crisis and manage to be at the focal point of its resolution? Well, you’ll have to read the book to find out, but I assure you: the plot is utterly unbelievable. But heck, this is supposed to be blockbuster commercial fiction. It may be over-the-top and downright silly in parts, but it kept me reading and entertained. Despite the ugly political distortions and exaggerated two-dimensional characters, I felt there was enough decent commercial fiction, suspense, and tension to earn it at least three stars.

After finishing the book, I reread a few Michael Palmer obituaries and was stunned to realize how much Lou Welcome mirrors the author’s own personal real life story. Both Dr. Lou Welcome and Dr. Michael Palmer had early careers as emergency room doctors; both men became addicted to pain killers, drugs, and alcohol and, partially as a result, lost their beloved wives to divorce; both men were disciplined by the medical profession and ended up serving in a volunteer capacity for a physicians-wellness organization assisting medical personnel with their substance abuse problems; both men eventually went into private practice in internal medicine. But the resemblance ends there. Lou Welcome is, of course, younger, brighter, stronger, more athletic, a greater risk taker, a more loyal friend, a more supporting father, etc. You get the picture? Lou Welcome is a fictional hero; he’s also, certainly, Michael Palmer’s tailor-made alter ego.

As a medical doctor with a long history of substance abuse and recovery, Michael Palmer has been quoted as saying that he started writing suspense thrillers as a type of long-term personal therapy. “When it comes to writing,” he said, “I loved the feeling of being in control when my life was not.” Well, none of us are in control of the current political debate that is dividing our Nation. I’m sure no matter which side you’re on, you’re probably immensely frustrated with your inability to control the situation. Obviously in this, his last book, Palmer was able to craft a plot that allowed him to not only be the heroic star of his own fictional world, but also a man capable of slaying his own private political dragon. I’m sure he derived a great deal of satisfaction writing this book. You decide if you will enjoy reading it.

Personally, I’m pleased I read it. If nothing else, it gave me a glimpse of psychological insight into the real-life author behind the book.

Dr. Michael Palmer, may you rest in peace along with your alter ego, Dr. Lou Welcome.

title: Terrible tale, terrible characters, terrible ending
text: I absolutely hated reading this “memoir”. I finished it because my book club will be discussing it, but I wish I hadn’t. Apart from not being able to connect to a single character, the writing is thin. The story itself has a sensational air about it and it seems a bit far-fetched. But if it’s all true, then I am angry at the fact that no one—not the neighbors, the grandparents, nor the clergy or medical staff —ever questioned the family about the abuse nor reported it to the authorities. True, the parents avoided most authority figures, but others knew what was going on in that family everyday, including Tara. I understand that she was a victim when she was a child living in the home, but when she left and finally sought counseling in college, the bishop and later her counselor both knew about the abuse that was STILL ongoing in the family. When I read about the dog, I almost threw up. I’m very upset that in her EDUCATED path to enlightenment, Tara forgot about her sister-in-law and children, and other family members who were trapped in the abusive dysfunction. Achieving a Ph.D, obviously did not give her the fortitude to help those family members who could not help themselves. I can’t help but wonder...what is your brother Shawn doing right now, Tara?

title: A chore to finish

Luckily I read this through "Kindle Unlimited" because I would not pay $ 2.99 for it. Alex, the heroin is obviously rather unintelligible and almost suicidal most of the time. Even when told she could be harmed or charged with investigation interference she does not seem to care. Thank heavens she has Tony for a hero, at least he keeps her alive for her next stupid move.

I have no idea why she thought that this one would be worth reading. It's pointless....not funny....she seemed to be reaching for things to say.

I was very disappointed.

title: You can count on this
text: I can always count on a Patterson series to be interesting and diverting, even if the characters are not multi-dimensional.

title: Ok but a little slower
text:
Oddly there are very few biblical fiction books that take place during biblical times or involve people of the Bible. It must be Amish fiction sells too well. That or authors seem to be nervous of being termed heretics.

With the first Noah book I enjoyed (Grade - B) and I like Chaffey's writing. Noah feels like a real person. He goes through character development. You understand his feelings and motivation. All the things you're supposed to do in a story. In this book, we pick back up with Noah from his just married happy ending. Oh and running away from the crazy princess who loves snake gods.

Throughout the book, Noah is written as being more of a leader and husband and friend. There are a lot of his personal aspects that are enjoyable to read. He also faces doubt and indecisiveness at times. Since we know the end story, this growth of Noah is really nice to see. He's not perfect and he's not holier-than-thou. The supporting cast of characters is interesting with Noah's friends being well written and sees Noah as a leader of the group. However, it's not like the hang on his every word and always need to be around him. There's a character who kind of gets a hero's speech in the middle of the book and it was nice that a supporting character could have that spotlight. The plot makes sense of where it's going and there are some neat highpoint scenes that are fun to read.

What the story had working against it was time factors. We Noah leads a long life but the jump in years of hundreds is really a big thing to do. This isn't like a character needing to advance in age by "5 years later" to get to their next plot point. Nothing happened of note to Noah in the 600 year time gap? On the other end of the spectrum, there is a lot of meandering plotting that happens. Some of this is the result of the slow travel by boats but there is a lot of travel to one place then back home and then back to the one place again and then off to a side trip. Noah's wife also feels like just a side character with kind of the normal thinking you'd probably guess she would have. It would have been interesting to have her challenging Noah's ideas or turning Noah to a correct understanding of God's character. She not a bad character but she just falls into a normal side character. The villains also aren't that well presented. It's the typical villains get power and so now they act crazy growth. It would have been neat to see pagan leaders develop the system of worship without being on the verge of madness and show that while the evil is growing to show the need for the Flood, they are people. They feel more like bad guy archetype characters than characters who are bad.

Overall, a decent read with some slow parts in the middle and some location changes that happen quickly that I'm not sure how certain characters get to where they're at. But with the knowledge that the Flood is coming, we know not all these characters can be with us for long and some neat plot points make it a good read and will want to continue the journey. Final Grade - C+

title: A beautiful model at the pentacle of her career leaps to ...
text:
<I>Cuckoo's Calling</I> was interesting right from the start. A beautiful model at the pentacle of her career leaps to her death, the tragedy extensively splashed over every television, magazine and website. From there the narrative is shared from two very different perspectives. Robin Ellacott, a young woman recently moved to London and more importantly, over the moon excited about her new engagement to her longtime boyfriend Matthew. Cormoran Strike (who just goes by Strike) a detective who’s business and personal life is spiraling out of control.

I don’t know exactly what changed but I became less enthusiastic about reading it. Normally I JUMP at any opportunity to sit and loose myself in a novel; also I have a personal goal to read at least 50 pages a day. However, I was content reading a chapter a day of Cuckoo. The characters are well developed and I had no clue “who did it,” yet I still wasn't excited to sit and read more. I think the ground work is laid with this series though and the next book will be more attention grabbing throughout

title: Not Completely Hopeless
text:
Evie is a 24-year-old who has run away from graduate school, her family, her boyfriend and all of her acquaintances. She's a bit of a stray. Evie was once kicked out of yoga class for staring, and in graduate school she developed a cocaine habit.

Evie pays tuition to become a dog trainer at The Mountaintop School For Dogs, which is run by a handful of ex-nuns. But first, she must become acclimated by spending time at the nearby Inn, managed by Mrs. Auburchon. There she makes the acquaintance of a teenager nicknamed "Giant George," as well as many rescued dogs.

The human characters in this book seem to be part dog, and the dogs seem to be somewhat human.

Since I've not read any other books by Ellen Cooney, I do not know if the free-association style is typical of her writing, or if it is used to show how Evie processes information.

However, all does not seem completely hopeless -- Evie does experience growth.

One thing I really did like about this story was the way the characters accept each other despite their mannerisms and eccentricities.

title: Typical celebrity biography
text: I love Paul Anka & have seen him perform many times over the years.  His autobiography goes into detail about his career and his friendships with other celebrities, which is interesting, but there is not much detail about his personal life in this book.

title: Something out of sync
text: The biggest disappointment for me in this psychological thriller was the unconvincing portrayal of the heroine, Dr. Anna Fox. The author is a male, but he chooses to tells this story through his main character who is a woman. Only thing is, nothing about her portrayal as a female is at all female to me. Nothing rings true, not even a little bit. Nothing maternal,where maternal is called for, nothing sexy about her in any detail of the plot where such would be expected,  nothing soft, simply bogus. Even her appearance is somehow out of sync with what we know. She is 30-something, but in every description I’m seeing a septuagenarian, or older. Very weird choices have been made by the author . Also, his overdosing us with her alcohol and drug habit is cloying. Enough already!  I get it; she uses substance to get through having been traumatized by events, but at the rate we witness her imbibing and drugging, she would not even be able to notice anything from her windows, were she even able to remain conscious enough to see out of them, and yet, the author asks us to suspend  our logic as he wants us to believe him as much as she wants to convince the police that she saw what she saw. All too tedious and really got hideously in the way of what could have been a pretty good read. I just did not like this book. No literary merit here that I could find. This plot is pretty conventional, so at the end of the day, to be outstanding, an author would have to really work on character development and details presented in a fresh and lyrical way,

title: A quirky, too short personal history
text: Jonathen Franzen's personal history is more a short collection of slightly disorganized life happenings than what one would usually expect in a memoir. He begins with the story of the sale of his mother's house after her death, located in "just right" Webster Groves, Missouri, where he grew up. His goal to obtain the highest possible price doesn't work out entirely as planned. Chapter Two, My Ponies, concerns Snoopy, with whom he felt a certain "kinship," and Peanuts comic strip creator Charles Schultz. Joy Breaks Through follows the antics of his teen youth group members, of which he shares some great words of wisdom (p 113): "Adolescence is best enjoyed without self-consciousness, but self-consciousness, unfortunately, is its leading symptom," and "You're miserable and ashamed if you don't believe your adolescent troubles matter, but you're stupid if you do." More on his teens follows in Centrally Located, especially the details of some high school pranks (complete with sketches). Learning German abroad is main subject of The Foreign Language. My Bird Problem contains a bit on romance and marriage, his changing awareness of and concern about the environment, and, likely the favorite part for birders, funny anecdotes about bird sightings at the Santa Ana Wildlife Refuge as well as his experiences as a bird watcher on Hat Island. Good as is, but fans will likely be left wanting more. Similarly satisfying: A Heartbreaking Work of Staggering Genius by Dave Eggers and Me Talk Pretty One Day by David Sedaris.

title: I knew I'd love this book.  I was wrong
text:
When this book arrived I rushed to my bookcase to pull down my 1922 edition of The Boston Cooking-School Cook Book. It was a slightly newer version than the one this book was based on, but I still expected that it would be fun to read Fannie's Last Supper and compare it with my disintegrating copy of the cook book, imagining what it would be like to put together a dinner party with recipes from 1896. I should have left Fannie on the shelf and taken several other, newer cookbooks instead.

It was a few days before I figured that out, though. I started by reading from the beginning, at the author's story of buying an 1859 Victorian bowfront in Boston. It was, apparently, not a pleasant place to live, with drug dealers on the sidewalk and a working girl with a customer in the neighbor's doorway. The author confronted drug dealers, got ripped off by neighborhood children, and joined a historical society, and his family was robbed at gunpoint and attended a gay wedding, though not at the same time.

All this might make an interesting book, and if I had wanted to read about relocating to South Boston in the 1990s I might have enjoyed it. Eventually I got to the first recipe, Victoria Punch, "courtesy of Donald Friary", who is "an expert on punch and punch bowls and a fellow member of Boston's St. Botolph Club". This was a bit of a surprise since Fannie Farmer had 15 punch recipes, including one for Victoria Punch which has nothing in common with Friary's. But Friary's recipe looks far less sweet and contains ingredients which would probably be easier to find, so perhaps that's the reason for the substitution.

The next chapter introduces Fannie Farmer a bit. "For starters, she was middle-class at best," it begins. Apparently poor Fannie could not have afforded a membership in St. Botolph Club, even if women had been permitted to join in her lifetime. We are, however, assured of Kimball's standing, since later in this chapter he discusses cooking dinner with his good friend Julia Child. One of the two recipes in this chapter, Brown Bread, is based on a Fannie Farmer recipe. The other recipe, Champagne Mignonette (to be served with oysters) has no source that I can find, but doesn't appear in my copy of the Cook Book.

While several other recipes seem to rely on cookbooks published at a point in time near Fannie Farmer's cookbook, such as Escoffier's Le Guide Culinaire, other sources include The Joy of Cooking and Gordon Ramsay. Salmon is grilled, a method not even mentioned in the Cook Book. The one common element throughout the book seems to be a certain level of scorn for Fannie Farmer. "What she may have lacked as a talented cook she made up for with a keen sense of showmanship, marketing, and giving the public what it wanted."

I admit that a big part of my problem with this cookbook is that I could not get past my expectations of "Two Years, Twelve Courses, and Creating One Amazing Meal from Fannie Farmer's 1896 Cookbook". It took me a few days to read most of the book, and two years to convince myself to pick it up again and read the last two chapters. Many parts of the book are quite enjoyable, especially the discussion of handling foods that modern cooks rarely use, like the calf's head. If the book had been marketed as a study of cookbooks from that time period (and if current sources had not been used,) I would have enjoyed it a great deal more.

title: Engrossing second chance love story
text:
Jane Porter returns to her Rhode Island hometown to help her sister care for their ailing mother. Jane rarely makes the trip due to the painful memories that have scarred her even into adulthood. When she was a sophomore in college, her mother forced her to give up her child for adoption, and it was handled privately, with the baby girl going to a local family.

Dylan Chadwick has also returned home. After his wife and daughter were killed in a crossfire while he was a US Marshall, he has returned to the family apple orchard, determined to bring it back to life. He has forged a loving and protective relationship with his niece, who it turns out, is the child that Jane gave birth to 15 years earlier.

Coming home affords Jane with the opportunity to meet the child she could never forget. Soon, she is spending time with Dylan, who has suddenly come out of his shell, and has fallen for her. She too is smitten with Dylan, but worries that her motivations for being with him will be misconstrued once he finds out about her relationship to Chloe.

Dance with Me is an absorbing story about two lost souls who manage to find each other, only to find themselves at odds. The icy relationship between the sisters and the mother is believable and engrossing.

title: Difficult to understand the Many Worlds Interpretation
text:
I bought this book so that I could understand the details of the Many Worlds Interpretation of quantum mechanics. I was disappointed that Peter Byrne does not address how the Many Worlds Interpretation addresses a key quantum mechanics experiment, the Double Slit Experiment. This experiment is particularly challenging for Many Worlds because the possible outcomes are both infinite and not discrete. The wave function could, theoretically, interact with any point on the screen and even points beyond it. And no point is discrete unless and until you reach the Planck length.

Byrne's explanation of Many Worlds begins understandably. But when he gets into the details like the role of probability, I could not understand his explanation. Many of Byrne's sentences are long and complex, which is part of the problem. I gave up and have learned more about Many Worlds from other books.

This book is much more valuable for the biographical information about Everett and the descriptions and quotations regarding the Copenhagen Interpretation than for the explanation of Many Worlds.

title: Coming of age story set in Paris
text:
The theme for the Mocha Girls Read book of the month in January was Paris. As a group, we voted to read Black Girl in Paris by Shay Youngblood. This relatively short and extremely beautiful book was essentially a coming of age story for its protagonist, Eden, and a lovely way to kick off 2019.

Black Girl in Paris is the story of a young lady and budding writer who picks up from her home in the United States with a little money and travels to Europe in search of the greatness that author James Baldwin wrote about. While there she encounters many people while trying to make a living and find creative inspiration in Paris.

One thing I found it interesting about this book is that Youngblood set it in the 80s while writing it in the millennium. It could have just as easily been set in the time in which it was written. I suspect the author may have done this to demonstrate just how far way from home Eden traveled. With the technology today (and in the early part of the turn of the century), it's so much easier to be close even when there's great physical distance.

Black Girl in Paris reads like a collection of chronological essays. Youngblood's prose is excellent and you want to follow her as a writer and Eden as the main character on this journey of self discovery. This book definitely kept me interested. This is not something I would have read but for book club. And that is one of the greater purposes of book club. I am glad I was able to partake and participate.

My ultimate takeaway from this story is that we cannot escape racism no matter the time nor location.

Recommendation: If you love Paris and the pursuit of one's dreams, this quick read might pique your interest.

Until next time ... Read on!

Regardless of whether I purchase a book, borrow a book, or am gifted one, my ultimate goal is to be honest, fair, and constructive. I hope you've found this review helpful.

I couldn’t convince myself to take the demon seriously, the ending left me unsatisfied, and the short story in the end did not help relate to Bethany any better. I'm not sure that the POV of someone just traumatized by gang rape is the proper element in which to develop this story; I needed distance, cold space to breath in, and this was simply missing.

title: Eve Dallas novella -- a fun enough ghost story
text:
And so this JD Robb novella, “Haunted” {#22.5 in the prolific “In Death” series}, is basically a ghost story. When Homicide Lt. Eve Dallas catches a death at the former NYC nightclub “12”, she discovers, while searching the building, yet another body – just a skeleton actually – complete with a gun laying nearby. Almost unbelievably, the gun {such weapons are now banned in our 2060 Gotham!} was the murder weapon in both deaths, probably separated by five decades or so, leading to the speculation that the skeleton belongs to a famous singer who disappeared a long time ago and now haunts “12”. Various mysterious apparitional appearances and sounds lead to the ghostly rumors, about which Eve and hubby Roarke have a snitty argument. Naturally, Eve works the case and will eventually solve both murders, but it takes her a good while to out the somewhat surprising perp.

160 pages in this edition make for an entertaining hour plus of reading – and probably one’s enjoyment will vary directly with the fun generated by the haunted angle. We might quibble that to us the ending didn’t quite hang together, but nonetheless an amusing enough outing.

title: If you did not want my opinion, you should not have bought my book.
text:
I will establish that I am conservative, but open-minded. I know my biases and have safeguards in place already. I teach classes on critical decision making techniques. I like to hear both sides of a topic, and I like them to be well-argued.

I purchased the book after other reviews convinced me the material had something to offer. I found that it is a one-sided view of the topics. It is hard to read a book that is filled with such a negative view of the way things have become. It offers soft evidence that smells of confirmation bias. In fact, one of the good things about it is to use it as an example of confirmation bias training. So I do not feel too bad that I had purchased this book. I just prefer all the facts be laid out, then the let the author play to his opinions; he should defend his and objectively take apart the opposing views.

His passion in his writing is so strong, I almost feel him standing over my shoulder deriding my views of his comments with "If you did not want my opinion, you should not have bought my book."

While I am sure the author is passionate about his opinions and that has created his negativity, he is entitled to them. He is entitled to publish them and defend them. After all is said and done, that is what the purpose of some of those topics he is so critical of. I think his opinion, the right to express it and the fact that it is published without fear of retribution stand as a monument to the successes of his targets of admonition.

I have actually read a bit of this book and it's pretty good. Tanya will probably become a successful author with multiple books. But I don't think I'll read another one after discovering this fraud.

title: A bit uneven at first, but more coherent in the final section
text:
To me, this seems to be a case where I liked the author’s intentions, but didn’t like how these intentions were carried out in the book. Our protagonist, Laurus, wear many hats and carries several names throughout the book, and perhaps that is a symbolic gesture to his always searching for meaning, identity and redemption.

There is a rambling and a bit incoherent quality to much of the beginning parts to Laurus, and for that reason alone, it was sort of a slog and struggle to try to push onward. This is especially evident in the first two sections. There is a bit of structure in the opening part, where we learn the back story of the protagonist and his uncle, and how he begins his life journey, as well as the tragedy that inspires him to begin his quest. However, in the second part of the book, we are hit with episode after episodes of healing and such, and it just seemed a little too random, aimless and sporadic.

As far as the text itself, I found some of book clunky with wording and expressions and I think it was just a translation issue or something. I also wasn’t a big fan of some of the magical realism that came out of nowhere.

Also, there are several shifts in time that seemingly come out of nowhere and are quite random. One reviewer mentioned how it felt like stories were just thrown in in any order with no relevance or coherence. I agree with that assessment, especially as we proceed into the second part of the book.

That being said, I think the best parts of the book are the final ones, and those made it worth the reading experience. I did enjoy several parts, such as the latter sections of Arseny’s pilgrimage to Jerusalem and the spiritual and physical quest he undertakes to get there. Much of this journey is a sense of coming to terms with his guilt over a particular tragedy, and seeking redemption. So, to me, this section not only flowed with much more structure and precision, but the themes were more prevalent as well.

I heard many comparisons to the likes of Umberto Eco and Fyodor Dostoevsky. However, I think those comparisons were a little too ambitious. Not a bad read, but just a tad too uneven and clunky.

title: Middle grade fiction just misses the mark
text: I wanted to like this book more than I did, and I recognize that it is loved by many. I found that I was again and again put off by Ruthie's references to the "dumb class" throughout this novel. As an adult reader, I drew some conclusions. I assumed that ESL children were sometimes placed in remedial classes without regards to other options or additional supports. I also assumed that the author may have had a real-life experience as a child with this worry because Ruthie would not let it go. Ever. The notes at the back of the book confirmed this. I admit that I sped through the last half of the book waiting for Ruthie to articulate her frustration with misplacement of ESL children while also showing some humanity for all of the children who were assigned to the remedial class. If that happened aside from her thanks in receiving a get-well card from the class, I did not see it. This ongoing fear of being a student in this class and commentary from Ruthie made it difficult for me to care for her in the way a reader usually cares for a child protagonist of a book. I feel like this is a book that would cause more damage than good in a read-aloud. I loved the connection to Nancy Drew, Cuba, Poland, refugees, Jose Marti, Frida Kahlo and the infusion of so many cultures within her world. I liked that the central problem of healing, isolated from her usual world and activities, is not one often seen in middle grade novels. It's something that does become a reality for kids dealing with injuries and illnesses, and they should be able to see this represented in the pages of a book. By the end of the book, I found myself more interested in the untold stories of the children in the class that Ruthie scorned. I understand that this may be an unpopular opinion, and this book will do fine without my praise. If I could send Ruthie a book to read while she healed, it would be Hunt's Fish in a Tree.

title: Ok  But ......
text:
First let me say I really like this author she has a great writing style. This book I feel is not her best work.

The storyline centers on a group of people who are hiding from the Nazis in a forest with the help of a girl who spent her life growing up in the same forest after being kidnapped.

If you're looking for a WWII Resistance story this is not the book for you. If you're looking for a book that borders on a fantasy story with a little WWII worked into it then this is the book for you.

Without giving too much away in case you want to read it I will say I was disappointed in the book. It was way to easy to predict the ending which is unusual for Harmel. Some parts just didn't seem to fit some parts were slow with too many descriptive phrases.

If you're looking for a good book from this author I recommend The Room on Ru Amelie also, 2 other books about the Resistance which are great are Dragonfly by Leila Meacham or A Fire Sparkling by MacLean.

title: Two Stars
text: Superficial

title: Just get the unannotated version.
text:
Text by Norton Juster; illustrations by Jules Feiffer; annotations by Leonard S. Marcus - too much to fit in the Subject: line!

When I was in - approximately - third grade, _The Phantom Tollbooth_ and Madeleine L'Engle's _A Wrinkle In Time_ alternated in my mind as the Best Book In The World, depending, basically, on which one I had read more recently.

As an adult, Martin Gardner's _Alice_ Annotations brought those books to greater life for me than they had ever had before.

I was, therefore, expecting a fair amount from _this_ book.

Expectations are a prison for the mind. One has to be happy with what one has to be happy with.

In other words: I was disappointed.

Not _completely_ disappointed, mind you. There's a lovely introduction relating the lives of Juster and Feiffer and how _TPT_ came to be - and also making me aware of a musical with lyrics by Sheldon Harnick. I'll have to check that out at some point, but right now I have this review to write.

That introduction is the best thing Marcus has added to the book. The actual annotations are quite variable: some of them repeat information in the introduction; some of them contain information about mid-century America that might be interesting to someone younger than I, but as I recall much of it from my own life it kind of washes over me; and a very small percentage tell me things I didn't know.

Perhaps the dullest annotations are the ones where Marcus attempts to explain the jokes. This is a bit odd, because some of my favorite annotations in _Alice_ are explanations of jokes - but they explain jokes that I wouldn't have gotten without them, because I lack the context of a Victorian Oxonian logician. A number of Carroll's jokes have passed their best-by date, and Gardner refreshes them somewhat.

This isn't true here. The jokes in _TPT_ are about matters a schoolchild of the current generation will understand. As in _Alice_, there are some asides that are addressed more to grownups than to children; perhaps some precocious child would find annotations of these asides valuable, but no actual adult is likely to have any use for them.

So I'm afraid I must judge this book fairly harshly. I enjoy rereading the _Tollbooth_ now and then, but - other than the introduction - this adds very little to the joy of the reread. I probably won't haul this heavy tome down from the shelves very often.

title: Confused til the end...then irritated
text: So throughout this book I could not figure out what was going on in the book. At the end of the book, the author quickly explains what was really happening throughout the book despite there being no indication this was the case while I was reading it. It felt like the explanation was just tacked onto the end to "easily" explain everything that did not make sense in the book.

title: Different but a little predictable
text:
Grace Mueller is a con artist and if you can't stand unlikable characters this book probably isn't for you. She's the mother of two and in order to keep up their lifestyle she comes up with some crazy moneymaking schemes and eventually everything spins out of control.

While the book was entertaining enough as I half rooted for Grace to get caught for her schemes and also half wanted her to get away, I didn't really feel like this was the most satisfying read. There were just too many things that were meant to be surprising that were fairly predictable. The action went back and forth between present day and Grace's past which was supposed to enlighten the reader to why she was the way she is but it fell a little flat. I wouldn't go out of my way to recommend this book but I did like that Grace was not your typical female character.

Thank you First to Read for the opportunity to read an advance digital copy! I was under no obligation to post a review and all views expressed are my honest opinion.

title: A very good start to an interesting new series
text:
Vanessa has a fabulous way of telling a story, so fabulous it's difficult to put the book down to see to other important things, like sleeping for instance.

I do have one request though, that there be in the near future a female character with a stronger personality. Many female friends I know have endured deep wounds in their past which left them with emotional and physical pain, but they don't dwell on that past on daily basis. I myself would not have developed into the strong person I am had I dwelled as often as Vanessa' s heros do on wounds inflicted in my past. Inward reflections are character building for sure, we must not forget how we got to where we are, strong and empathetic women. When I would have a need to spend time trying to understand my stories by talking about them among close friends, there be those who would sympathize, comparing their past to mine, and those who shut down because they were too entangled in their own that there just isn't room for others', they didn't want to hear about my painful memories. But there were always a couple listening and deciding on the spot, was I stuck with my past or was there something to learn from my story and who I am in the present, does my present reflect my past in positive ways. They have empathy.

The character Yvonne, the main character in this story, and Arrow , the main character in the last series by Nelson, both feature a wanne-be-strong female characters, but both fail continuously. They never really stop remembering and flinching from their past, there is just too much concentration put on remembering and reliving their painfully past and feeling anxiety. We don't see her deriving strength from these revisiting, she doesn't seem to benefit from such ruminations, the reactions are always the same, weakness not strength, With a MC villain or hero, either way they need to be strong, living fully in the present. Neither Arrow nor Yvonne represent examples of how I describe strong women, the kind of women, who in spite of adversity, or because of them, are real role models, the kind I want for the up-and coming next generation of young women to emulate. Our daughters need strong examples of heros in stories they read, heros who use injustice, adversaries, emotional and physical pain suffered, covert these type of experiences into empathy, certainly not anxiously comparing every new situation with experiences from a difficult past . The future of this world will be resting on strong and empathetic female leaders, heros. I personally want to feel empowered by the heroines in the stories I am reading, and like most readers I have experienced eye opening AHA moment from insightful storytellers and it's one reason why I love reading. Maybe digging a little deeper this talented writer too will find just such a heroine ready to reveal herself.

Her stories are well told, we come to know every character, the world they live in and why they do what they do too, eventually. This deep understanding Vanessa has of her story is very obvious. Her attention to details do not distract from the suspense and adventures, (I wish there was a map, my memory isn't what it used to be). The unexpected keeps me reading with anticipation. In the first book of this series we are made familiar with the characters, the world they live in and to a point, what direction the events will flow, what to expect.

It works and flows well, until about chapters 23 onwards. Here it suddenly becomes confusing because the detailed background we been given doesn't fit, suddenly don't seem true anymore, and also suddenly got very dark. I became confused about the story. What unfolded was all wrong, the connection severed, so much didn't fit with the background information I been reading this far. I'm still confused as to what suddenly happened, but then I skipped over several pages because they just didn't sound right. I actually skipped many of the last pages. There is also some violence which seemed over the top and the whole setup unbelievable even for fiction. I was unable to imagine the descriptions of events unfolding and actions taken by the characters, numbers and scenes contradicting themselves from one paragraph to the next - there was an unexplained number of mercenaries which seemed to come out of nowhere, the numbers of slaves, the description of the scenes impossible and not what was said earlier. This entire section just didn't make sense. It feels as if the writer was struggling to keep the story together, make sense. That is a real shame, because the story up until that point has been so well setup, the details are carefully planned and developed over time, preparing us for a well thought out story which would be told over several books. I will read book two based on the care with which Vanessa has taken, and the promise that entails for the quality of the full story yet to unfold. I feel it would be too early and too harsh to dismiss the whole story.

title: Yawn
text:
I cannot imagine how this book was ever optioned for a motion picture. The writing is weak, the pacing off, and characters cliches.

The story sounded interesting and I was looking forward to reading it. Very disappointed in the book.

One other reviewer suggested it ws a good beach book....well, in my opinion, only if you want to fall asleep on the beach.

Skip this one. There are lots of other good books out now that will not be a waste of money. Frankly, I'll skip the movie, too.

title: NOT Play in DVD Player ONLY in Computer
text:
Description
Interactions is a series of CD-ROMs (or DVD) focusing on the examination of physiological processes within each system of the body, using animations and interactivity to enhance student understanding. There is a great deal more to Interactions than your usual A&P CD-ROM. At the heart of Interactions is a focus on core principles – homeostasis; communication; energy flow; fluid flow; and boundaries – that underscore the key relationships between structure and function as well as interrelationships between systems. It is the reinforcement of these fundamental organizing principles, to which a variety of processes and concepts for each system is attached, that sets this series of CDs apart from others.

There are nine CDs in the series. These include:

Foundations
Regulations: The Nervous and Endocrine Systems
Support and Movement: The Skeletal and Muscular Systems
Distribution: The Cardiovascular and Lymphatic Systems
Disease Resistance: The Integumentary, Lymphatic and Immune Systems
Energy Acquisition and Use: The Digestive System and Metabolism
Gas Exchange and pH Balance: The Respiratory System
Balancing Fluids and pH: The Urinary System
Continuity: The Reproductive System and Development

title: Informative, But Only Introduction
text:
The observance of the seventh-day Sabbath has been a contentious issue amongst many Christians for centuries in Europe and North America, but one place that may startle many is that it has been the same in Africa. In his book "Sabbath Roots: The African Connection", Charles E. Bradford brings to light many tribal and cultural customs from across the continent giving the reader evidence of the memory and observance of the seventh-day Sabbath from all corners of Africa.

With over 2000 years of Biblical history as well as cultural studies of hundreds of tribes across an entire continent as well as the African diaspora to the Americas, Bradford had many sources to navigate and reference to give readers a sense of how Africans fit into the continuing debate on the Sabbath. Beginning with how God is seen from the Biblical prophets and how He is perceived in the minds of Africans on both the continent and diaspora, Bradford brings to light where each stands to the other. Afterwards, he delves into the subject of the Sabbath on the African continent in relation to God and to cultures in and outside of Africa. Finally Bradford turns his attention to the history of Christianity on the continent, with a main focus on colonial period which it was considered both a forced religion from the outside and a religion of protest from foreign occupation.

In roughly 230 pages, Bradford had to cover a lot over a wide scope of scholarship and while he did a remarkable job in an engaging text and strong use of numerous sources there was only so much he could do and does leave readers with questions. The biggest and most important issue deals with the Sabbath itself. Outside the well-known Black Jewish groups, the Falasha and the Lemba, and writing briefly about the Jewish diaspora in Africa, Bradford does indicate if the cultural and tribal traditions of the seventh-day Sabbath across the continent are all from Jewish contact or a mixture of Noahide memory and contact with Jewish influences. This lingering question while not invalidating Bradford’s thesis, does leave it up to interpretation.

Although the question of when Sabbath entered into the cultural traditions of tribes all over Africa is unanswered, "Sabbath Roots" is still a very welcome addition to information about the seven-day Sabbath. But Bradford’s book should only be considered an introduction, especially in relation to Africa, and should inspire readers to look for more information after reading.

title: Copy and paste
text:
Well, this is another one of those "copy and paste" pseudo-biographies about rock bands, where the author puts together only second-hand information already published in other sources and does not interview any of the badn member or even their close personnel.

Anyway, if you're not the kind of person that wants to read everything about the band you like (as myself)and, since there is no official Van Halen biography around, this is a satisfactory place to star reading about the band's history.

title: So so-so.
text:
Disclaimer: This review is shaped by personal opinion, contains modest spoilers, and is only possible because of the hard work of the author(s) who wrote this book (to whom, for better or worse, I am grateful).

The way this book leapt to the top of the bestsellers lists and the middle of magazine Arts & Culture pages, I confess to high expectations. Surely this mystery must have extra turns; surely this thriller trenchantly examines a current problematic social trend; surely the protagonist must be more humanly flawed than most and must be compelling and nuanced! What I read instead was a perfectly fine, perfectly mystery/psychological thriller. Sure, the bending of reality via flawed perception is in the zeitgeist; this is another treatment on the topic. Certainly mental health is an ever more prevalent concern; this book mentions some counseling and medication. At the end of the day willpower overcomes mental illness and I don’t know that this is the most positive message to convey. Willpower is certainly a part, but so are vulnerability and professional help and exercise and meditation and eating and community and a thousand (rough estimate) other factors. It’s a harrowing tale of a woman dragging herself through her agoraphobia and PTSD to help a neighbor, but it’s fanciful conception doesn’t match is somber, sober tone. An entertaining read, but not a book with a message I would endorse.

B-

title: Nothing wrong with the reproduction
text:
Other reviewers have complained about the reproduction quality of this book. I think that's wrong. It's actually quite fine...it's just not a style which is particularly fashionable right now or that calls attention to itself. The reproductions are done one picture to a page, with no bleeds and no crossing of the gutter. Point one in its favor. They are done with accurate color (i.e., not exaggerated color) and a full tonal range (i.e., accurate contrast, which might look low-contrast to people accustomed to looking at lots of pictures on flickr or elsewhere online, or to those who are free with the sliders in Photoshop). I've seen a number of these pictures in the original, in museums and at Magnum New York, and these reproductions are quite faithful.

Finally, the surface is only semi-matte, rather than the glossy plate which is most common in less expensive photo books and, especially, in magazines. Those used to looking at glossy surfaces, or who associate glossiness with quality, might find this lacking. It isn't. I actually like it better.

Although the reproduction quality is "democratizing," meaning it doesn't emphasize or exalt one picture over any others or go to any lengths to suggest original prints as unique objects, I actually found it to be one of the plus points about this book.

I reviewed this book more extensively at The Online Photographer under the title "Bon bons."

title: The Thirteen
text:
After being fired from her waitress job at a strip club, Paula Wittmore is notified that her mother has taken ill. She packs up her bags along with her teenage daughter, Rowan, and returns to her home town, a suburban called Haven Woods. Everything may look normal there, but Haven Woods has dark secrets at every corner, including several strange deaths and apparent suicides.

Returning home is putting Paula on an emotional rollercoaster as she reunites with some of her childhood friends, not to mention her mother's strange frenemies - twelve women bound by terrible secrets that requires a thirteen to be sacrificed.

I have seen other bloggers post about the Thirteen, and when I saw it on at my local library I had to check it out. It's an incarnation of The Stepford Wives and the short lived ABC series The Gates. The main character, Paula, is your typical prodigal child coming back to her hometown, in this case she is returning, with her daughter that she had when she was in her teens, to her hometown to take care of her mother, Audra's - who is part of a coven. The narrative does have that satire feeling to it, and I felt that the book was boring midway through. All the characters are interesting and the dialogue was crafted well. The Thirteen wasn't the best read, but it was mostly entertaining.

title: Not bad, could be a little more compelling.
text: My 15 month old son seems to like the illustrations, but I wouldn't say that the book/story itself is compelling enough to keep him interested. He usually seems to lose interest before we get to the end. However, I do often find him with this book, looking at the one page with all the things that "natures likes to build." I think he particularly likes the images on that page.

title: Truth Worth Telling--Just Not As Well Told As It Could Have Been
text:
Put together much like a 60 Minutes program, Truth Worth Telling moves between sometimes quite unrelated subjects and often without chronological order. Just as with 60 Minutes, all of the topics are important and meaningful even if they are not always at the top of daily news reporting. These are, admittedly, somewhat long on wartime kinds of stories, of dangerous assignments on the frontlines of Afghanistan and elsewhere. There is a lot of politics too, but that is to be expected from the kind of reporting Scott Pelley has been known for, and here he can be open about where his sympathies and leanings lie.

All in all, a pretty impressive memoir. Still, it didn’t end up being a very stirring story. The jumbling of stories doesn’t work as well in a book as in one-hour weekly TV segments, especially when the time line is also mixed up. Many of the stories are just a little too long, a little too detailed, to hold the reader’s interest to the end of the chapter. And, unless you are really into military stories, there are too many segments dealing with this topic.

Perhaps with a little more editorial pruning, perhaps at least 100 pages cut from the 400+ current length, this might have sustained my interest more. More importantly, a tighter narrative would have helped to illustrate what Pelley summarizes well in his four page conclusion, the real meaning behind his title, Truth Worth Telling.

title: Not what I was expecting

title: Three books for the price of one, but do you really need the third?
text:
I was thinking while I read this book, it could have been three books. The first one would be a very nice and serious book about growing up in South Africa as a clever girl: the title could be: "Said she, what am I doing here? (p.14). In spite of its funniness, it is also chaplinesque sad. Jonasson manages to write both funny and ironic - and sad. Which is an achievement.

The next book would be about South African policy, and its attempt to build nuclear weapons. The title could be "Hard times for P.W. Botha" (p.139). Assuming that the main political characters are described trustworthy, which there is no reason to believe that they are, and that the main characters of the story are just caricatures, which there is every reason to believe they are, this book will give good insight into some version of South African policy 1960- 1984.

The third book is about a pair of Swedish twins that were physical identical, but mentally contrasting. The title could be:" The twins and their King" The story is too bizarre to understand, the twins too close to caricatures that you feel anything for them and you don't see how they could exist, even within this bizarre universe " Holger 1 saw, felt and understood. Holger 2 did not see, did not understood. But he felt." (p. 132.) It is a little pity, I do think that a story about twins that have to live with an outside likeness and an inside dislike (-ness) would have been interesting. Also within Jonasson's literary style. Do I learn anything about Sweden, its society and its history? I guess so, within the same reality as Jonasson has on South African policy.

However, maybe the book still has to be three in one? I liked the two first part and swallowed the last part. Probably because the parts are stitched piecewise together so you do not really have a choice.

title: Difficult and lacking detail
text:
I am a fan of William Golding and I appreciate his attempts to illuminate the subject of prehistoric humans. Unfortunately, the three novellas included in this collection were very difficult for me to read, especially without context.

As I read the stories, I was frustrated with the lack of detail and context. Although I could place the characters and their actions, the stories dragged tremendously. After I read quiet a few reviews, I feel that I better understand the point of the stories. Nevertheless, the felt like a chore to read, especially compared to some of Golding's other works.

title: The Bibliography Should Make This A Keeper
text: The bibliography and annotations should make this a keeper, as it has become for me. Although I disagreed with the late Dr. Kofsky about the fundamental potential of the species H. sapiens (and thus remained a political opposite, far, far to his right), as his student I continue to marvel at his research a decade after his untimely death. I must concede that it has sadly gone to waste a bit in the text of this book--though good, it's not at all special in the company of its peers. I must also agree that its tendency toward Marxist religious banter (which must inherently replace logical conclusions in Marxist writing) reduces its academic value per se; none the less I still find it beautiful in its architecture. I can only hope that the breadth of his life's work fell intact into the hands of his graduate assistant, who took over instruction in his last days as a professor in Sacramento. Whether it has or not, this book is well worth considering, especially to a student designing his or her own research. Its annotations and bibliography promise an excruciatingly well investigated line of departure for any intended work on the period, right, left, or simply rational. Now, one last comment about the author: he himself was a graduate student of the Robert LeFevre-Howard Zinn lineage, with all its implications about revision of history to fulfil the prophesies of the sans-culottes. (Y'know, I miss the ol' grouch though too.)

title: Reads Like a Scooby Doo Mystery
text:
I have been waiting to read this book for a year, so I was quite disappointed that it didn't live up to the expectation I was harboring. For the past few years, Jayne Anne Krentz's historicals (written as Amanda Quick) have been sadly lacking. The heroes are no longer titled, the attraction between the heroes and heroines are no longer so ... I don't know ... what's the word ...primal, maybe? And now Quick is placing more emphasis on the mystery than on the relationship. Even then I'd have given the book a 4 if the mystery didn't read like something straight out of a Scooby Doo show.
Granted, Krentz/Quick is an author I'm more critical of than others because she's so exceptionally talented. Nevertheless, her historicals and contemporaries have both been missing that something special lately that makes it worth paying for a hardcover.
My advice is two-fold: (1) wait for the paperback and switch to her futuristics (under the name Jayne Castle). Her futuristics are still 5+ stars.

title: Time Displaced X-Men Visit Ultimate Spider-Man
text:
Collecting: All-New X-Men #31-36

In the previous episode, [[ASIN:0785154337 All-New X-Men Volume 5: One Down]], the time-displaced X-Men bested the Brotherhood of Evil Mutants. Now with a stronger sense of self confidence and with the adult X-Men away at the reading of Xavier's last will and testament (see [[ASIN:0785154892 Uncanny X-Men Volume 4: Vs. S.H.I.E.L.D.]] ), the young X-Men plus X-23 decide to investigate a new mutant sighting on the cerebro on their own.

As if the time-displaced X-Men weren't causing enough disturbance to the state of the universe, the new mutant appears to have the ability to open gateways throughout the multiverse. The X-Men are shunted from our universe (known as Earth 616) to Earth 1610-- a parallel Earth in the multiverse that is home of Miles Morales, Ultimate Spider-Man. Scattered throughout this alternate Earth, the X-Men are put to the test! Iceman finds himself fighting mole people in a very steamy Atlanta. Beast becomes the prisoner of Dr. Doom. Angel ends up in the Savage Land. And X-23 learns the origin of mutants in this alternate dimension! Jean Grey and Ultimate Spider-Man team up with this world's X-Men to set things right.

Writer Brian Michael Bendis seems a bit overly fond of time/space displacement, even if in this particular instance it was nice to see the time-displaced X-Men team up with Ultimate Spider-Man. That said, having the young X-Men meet older X-Men and then revealing that adult life didn't work out how the teens thought it might seems a little tired at this point. The Jean and Miles Morales moments were done well enough to save this volume, but it won't be remembered as a favorite.

The adventures of the young X-Men from the past who are stuck in the present continue in [[ASIN:0785192409 All-New X-Men Vol. 7: The Utopians]]

title: READ Title Carefuly!!!

title: The flashbacks are the most intriguing part of the book.
text: I found the flashbacks to be the most intriguing part of the book and the reason I kept reading. The story as a whole has an identity crisis. Is it a war story or an orphan werewolf story? Chapter numbers restart every time the story it flips between the character’s present and past, making them pointless. It would have been easier to follow and more enjoyable if the numbers remained sequential and the present and past switch each chapter. Didn’t much care about the big history lesson before the action started, or the revised history aspects. Secondary characters are a bit flat and stereotypical, especially the women.

title: Pretty book

title: A great concept weighed down by overcomplicated wordplay and a tone ...
text: A great concept weighed down by overcomplicated wordplay and a tone that becomes very didactic as the book goes on. The imagery can be surprising or it can be very stereotypical and expected: the heart is like a rose, this picture is a window to the soul, etc.

title: Misleading title
text: I bought this book hoping for in-depth information about training donkeys. Instead, I just got a chapter acknowledging that donkeys are different than mules and need to be trained differently. The entire rest of the book is about training mules. Interesting info, but not what I needed.

title: Not enough focus on sight words
text:
This set has 25 books and 50 sight words. Obviously, 2 sight words per book. Most of the words in each story are not sight words.

My son's school requires a lot of sight reading, so I'm always on the lookout for books with his sight words in them. This is not my favorite set. They could have put more than 2 sight words in each book, and made it less about phonics. To read these you have to know long vowels (the rules of silent e and double vowels), the rule that "ew" and "oo" can make a U sound, and other rules for sounding out words. But a student will probably be assigned all 50 sight words in the set before they get to all these other rules.

Also, some words in these books are just too big for the young beginning reader. Pepperoni and Butterflies, really? They have a picture of a pizza, or a picture of butterflies, to give the student clues what these big words are supposed to be. I prefer a book to have words that are on the right reading level for the child, to reinforce words they already know, and introduce a few new ones in each book. (Rather than having big, new words they have to guess from looking at pictures, throughout the whole book.) Some people will feel that learning through context and clues is the right way, but it's just not my preference.

The Bob Books Sight Words sets are more what I'm looking for. Simple words that don't rely so much on pictures, and more sight words per book. Also a word introduced in one book will appear in the next book, which will introduce 3 more words, so the set progresses from one book to the next. This Sight Word Readers set has no progression.

I don't think these are worth it for the price.

title: great for really young chilren
text: This was a great, fun book up to about 2 years old.  Now he's kind of board with it. But does a good job introducing some words and great for infant motor skills to lift the flaps and find surprises

text: If you have done any research at all on the internet then you pretty well know the same information that is in this book! title: Fourth Book in the Kendra Michaels Series
text:
I was given the opportunity to read an electronic copy of Night Watch via NetGalley and St. Martin's Press. This is my honest opinion of the book.

Kendra Michaels has just delivered a research paper at a conference on aging at Pepperdine University, regarding music therapy for Alzheimer patients when she sees Dr. Charles Waldridge. Responsible for the Night Watch project that helped to restore Kendra's sight nine years before, Waldridge goes missing just after meeting with Kendra. Enlisting the help of her friend Adam Lynch, along with Special Agent Michael Griffin of the FBI, Kendra starts her own investigation into the disappearance. Using the special skills that she has honed after years of living in the dark, Kendra soon discovers that there is a deeper mystery to Waldridge's disappearance. With danger swirling all around her, will Kendra be able to uncover the secrets and find the doctor before it is too late?

As the fourth book in the Kendra Michaels series, I was surprised to find out so many details about this character. Including important aspects of her backstory, the premise was interesting and really developed the character more than the previous books. Of course, it is totally implausible that Kendra would be granted access to crime scenes, but this is one of those plot points that you just have to accept. As well, Kendra is more knowledgeable than an internet search engine, which is completely unbelievable. Regardless of these facts, Night Watch is a fast paced thriller that is an interesting and quick read. I would recommend reading the Kendra Michaels books in series, as it is hard to learn all of the nuances of the character from just this book.

title: Sub-par space opera
text:
Evan Currie's "Into the Black: Odyssey One," a re-edit and re-package of Odyssey One (2011), according to Cleigh Currie (see discussion here: http://www.amazon.com/gp/forum/cd/discussion.html?ie=UTF8&cdForum=Fx376GGZL25AFA0&cdThread=Tx25E3DQ888YYJP), is not exactly David Weber, but then not much in the sci fi universe is for those of us who enjoy the best of military sci fi. Most definitely the description of the book as "a first-rate military science fiction epic that combines space opera and modern storytelling" is stretching things just a bit, and I'm being generous.

The story begins in the years after World War III, which took place as one might expect between and eastern and a western bloc. The protagonist, Captain Eric Weston is a fighter pilot who because of his heroics in the war has been promoted to captain the NAC (North American Confederation or simply `the Confed' and comprised of the U.S., Canada, and Mexico) ship Odyssey for a voyage of exploration into deep space (I should mention this is not exactly Star Trek either).

The explanation that Weston's "rather public position as the flight leader of the Archangels had put him on the short list to captain her" doesn't really explain why a fighter pilot is the best guy to captain a huge new prototype ship with an experimental drive on a voyage of intergalactic exploration. One would expect him to take command of a smaller ship first, or perhaps a staff position or perhaps command of all fighter defenses in the NAC. Certainly there must be officers who outrank him or have seniority. The reasoning seems to be that he is the hero, ergo he gets the ship, which isn't exactly how the military works.

In any event, Weston arrives on aboard his new command and takes it into space. One doesn't find the crisp military protocol of the Honorverse here either; it is reminiscent of Star Trek where a more comradely and less formal atmosphere prevails. We are not given any description of the Odyssey when Weston arrives to take command, as one might expect, viewing the mighty new ship from the exterior on his approach, or even when he enters, which would seem another good opportunity. As the ship leaves the vicinity of earth and heads toward Mars we know almost nothing about it beyond a brief description of its drive and that it is now home to Weston's old unit, the Archangels. We know precisely nothing about its actual mission. Star Trek, at least, gave us that information at the opening credits.

These deficits make getting into the novel difficult. By now I was only on page 22 and over 500 pages to go. I found myself hoping that things would pick up once they left our solar system but I was quickly disappointed. Apparently the Transition drive works something like a Star Trek transporter, at least in appearance and the crew watches their ship disintegrate, and then reconstruct itself at its destination. The Transition drive description again loses in comparison to David Weber's description of hyperspace travel. Science aside, I could feel the sense of wonder and beauty, reading Weber.

Arriving at Alpha Centauri they pick up some sort of distress call, identified as such by the "linguistic telepath" (I'm sorry, I started thinking Counselor Deanna Troi here) through means probably best not explained. It will take the Odyssey hours to clear Alpha Centauri's gravity well but rather than scout it, map it, scan it or even bother to look at it with anything approaching the wonder you'd expect, they sail right off on a 28-light-year journey to the distress signal. At this point I had pretty much lost interest in the entire enterprise (pardon the pun).

Things just seem sort of random, lacking any real internal consistency. For example, upon learning of the distress call Captain Weston asks his XO, "I don't suppose anybody we know is out there?" How could there by anybody they know out there, 28-light-years away, if as seems the case, they are the first such ship to leave earth? Do you really want to sound that stupid in front of your subordinates?

By page 56 I knew I had had enough. Arriving on the scene, the Captain decides he IS Captain Kirk and that his primary responsibility is not his own ship and crew, or even the mission (whatever that is) and that he can go running off in a shuttle to perform a rescue operation and let others worry about his responsibility. And what does he find? A pretty black-haired girl. I mean, look...nothing against Star Trek here. I enjoyed Star Trek. But this isn't supposed to be Star Trek - it's supposed to be a "first-rate military science fiction epic." Sadly, old-school space opera seems to be the primary element of this tale and not particularly well-written old school space opera. This whole thing was completely predictable. You knew if there was no pretty officer on the Odyssey that the first thing Captain Weston would do was find one.

No, Honor Harrington this is not. And it's not as though the writing is any great shakes either, as I said above. It's very light on descriptions and motivations. We don't know much about Captain Weston by page 56 and even less about his XO or any other crew members. We know next to nothing about the Odyssey itself and its capabilities (it took on fuel before leaving earth, but what kind of fuel? Reactor mass? What?), and still nothing about their mission, which seems to be along the lines of gallivanting around on the whim of the captain. The dialogue is not terrible but it's not great either and to be honest, the crew does not sound (or act) particularly military to me. Weston's XO is more his "friend" than his XO and I'm sorry, I wouldn't want to see my captain "slump" on the bridge in front of the crew. What kind of signal does that send? My seven-year-old would do that but I don't want my captain doing that.

I honestly can't find a single good thing to say about this book except the premise - space exploration. It should be full of wonder but there is no wonder described in this book, either from the author's third person perspective or in the thoughts of the humans who are experiencing it. Captain Weston's last thought on page 60 is "Command sucks" - unfortunately, so does this book.

title: At Least the Food Sounded Good
text:
Caution for some very, very vague spoilers and a larger spoiler that’s marked. The very last paragraph sums up my feelings without these.

What can I say about this book other than I am mystified that people consider this good writing. There is good writing trying to escape here, crawling around through the words shouting ‘please don’t go’ and perhaps with the level of editorial craftsmanship that Harper Lee had gotten this book would be excellent. The premise certainly was good but to me personally the execution was considerably lacking.

The general gist of the story is of Mattie, a 78 year old woman who is spritely and who we mostly follow throughout, and her adventures with finding a dog and then a juvenile delinquent on her doorstep. Sometimes the point of view switches to other characters and that’s one of the problems. On page three we met her son Robert and on page four we get a random thought process of him worried she’s alone and perhaps she should have a pet.

Does this happen often and consistently? No.

Instead this happens randomly throughout that we get into some character’s head at any moment and it simply seems to be a mechanism to tell us something that the author doesn’t know how else to put out there.

Then there is the telling. Oh bless the light do we get hit over the head with some things. Mattie on tells us in various parts all about what her children are, what they do, why she has issues with them. It’s an entire change in narration style to infodump on us. And it happens quite often that we get sudden spurts of information just pushed out there and left as though it is the only way to tell us these facts.

Strangely enough we also don’t get other critical information. While she tells us facts about her children we never get a sense of why they ae the way they are. All the details are the ones that float on the surface and anything that could be troublesome, those pesky reasons for character motivations or even real development that are tangled up and deeper down are never really addressed for anyone.

The thing is though, and this goes back to my comment on the good writing trying to get out, the author does have chances to tell us this information in a more natural way that fits more with the punchy short style he seems to prefer. Examples:

- Mattie has thoughts about buttons at one point which is poignant and gets across her feelings about certain things regarding her children far more naturally then her just randomly thinking Very Important Details of them while making lunch.

- After point blank telling us about how she doesn’t like a character Mattie drifts during a prayer thinking about said woman in a way that would have gotten that idea across and made me want to throw the book across the room because it was so much better.

- A gossiping character provides background information while on the phone and it feels exactly what this character would do. I wish there was more of this instead of the random dumps of character details we get.

[Spoiler]

This brings us to the ending which I will not talk about in any detail but re-reading the last few pages makes me wonder if Mattie is doing what she’s doing because it’s right or if it’s because she wants to fulfill her own needs which some may see as shellfish. I’m going with the latter, that she didn’t grow the way she should have to be able to get to the point where she’s doing what the book has talked about for over a hundred a pages of its length – to treat even the worst among us as well as if they were Jesus.

Not to mention what she’s going to do when her so called friends at her church turn around and bite her and she finds out after her supposed breakthrough. Especially after her daydreams about the warmth and healing nature of church and how that's going to tear her world apart. Or the reaction of her children since they already see her as lacking at her age and could take rather drastic steps to stop her. It’s a cliffhanger ending leaving us without a clear resolution of the cascade of events Mattie has started.

I suppose it’s just me but if you want to bring in events that could ruin a character’s life don’t add them to the end of a rather fluffy novel about a Southern lady who disarms all arguments with cooking.

[End Spoiler]

One reviewer I read wondered if the author actually liked his main character and after re-reading certain parts I want to agree with them and say no. In fact most characters were portrayed negatively especially the church women. While I won’t deny that I haven’t met women like this growing up in the church (I definitely have) or seen the behavior exhibited by them at the same time there was like no one good. No one that followed what was preached. I’d go so far to say as the only one the author actually sympathized with is Wesley since he actually got a much clearer redemption arc while almost everyone else merrily paved their path to hell.

Please remember that the above is my own personal opinion and that those who read this may find it the cats meow. To me it was a disappointment especially considering the plot of an older woman who is still independent. I grew up with grandmothers and great-grandmothers and even great-aunts who were like Mattie in terms of her activity level and they were like that into their nineties (minus the lawn mowing of course at that age!). I like seeing older protagonists in literature, especially women, and was disappointed greatly that Mattie herself seemed like an idealized version that wanted to change but in the end made me question if she had at all.
